revision.text:
{{featured article}} {{Chinese |s=国语罗马字 |t=國語羅馬字 |l="[[Standard Chinese]] [[Romanization]]" |p=Guóyǔ Luómǎzì |w=Kuo2-yü3 Lo2-ma3-tzu4 |myr=Gwóyǔ Lwómǎdz̀ |tp=Guóyǔ Luómǎzìh |mi={{IPAc-cmn|g|uo|2|yü|3|-|l|uo|2|m|a|3|zi|4}} |j=gwok3 jyu3 lo4 ma5 zi6 |y=gwok yu lòh máh jih |ci={{IPA-yue|kʷɔ̄ːk jȳː lɔ̀ː mɐ̬ tɕìː|}} |gr=Gwoyeu Romatzyh |poj=Kok-gí Lô-má-jī |piccap=
锅 鍋 guo
国 國 gwo
果 果 guoo
过 過 guoh
[[:File:Grguo.png|View this table as an image (for browsers unable to display Chinese characters)]]
The four tones of ''guo'' as written in characters (simplified on left, traditional on right) and Gwoyeu Romatzyh. Note the spelling differences, highlighted in red, for each tone.
}} '''Gwoyeu Romatzyh''' ([[pinyin]]: ''Guóyǔ luómǎzì'', literally "National [[Language]] [[Romanization]]"),{{zh|s=国语罗马字|t=國語羅馬字|p=Guóyǔ Luómǎzì}}. In 1937 the sinologist Trittel coined the German translation "Lateinumschrift der Reichssprache" (DeFrancis[1950]: Ch 4, footnote 4). abbreviated '''GR''', is a system for writing [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin Chinese]] in the [[Latin alphabet]]. The system was conceived by [[Yuen Ren Chao]] and developed by a group of [[linguistics|linguists]] including Chao and [[Lin Yutang]] from 1925 to 1926. Chao himself later published influential works in linguistics using GR. In addition a small number of other textbooks and dictionaries in GR were published in [[Hong Kong]] and overseas from 1942 to 2000. [[File:TPE-PWD-PSLO Taytzyy Greening Area stone 20160806.jpg|thumb|right|Gwoyeu Romatzyh in use on a park sign in Taipei. Taytzyy = 太子 = Tàizǐ]] GR is the better known of the two romanization systems which indicate the four [[Standard Chinese_phonology#Tones|tones of Mandarin]] by varying the spelling of syllables ("tonal spelling").The only other romanization system to utilize tonal spelling is [[Simplified Wade]], a modified form of [[Wade–Giles]] devised by Swedish linguist [[Olov Bertil Anderson]]. These tones are as fundamental to the Chinese language as vowels are to English; their presence [[Phoneme|lets speakers discriminate]] between otherwise identical syllables and words."A word pronounced in a wrong tone or inaccurate tone sounds as puzzling as if one said ''bud'' in English, meaning 'not good' or 'the thing one sleeps in.'" Chao(1948):24. Other systems indicate the tones with either [[diacritic]]s (for example [[Pinyin]]: ''āi, ái, ǎi'' and ''ài'') or numbers ([[Wade–Giles]]: ''ai1, ai2'', etc.). GR spells the four tones of the same vowel, ''ai'', ''ai'''r''''', ''a'''e''''' and ''a'''y'''''.In these examples ''air'' (''ái'') with a rising tone means "cancer", while ''ay'' (''ài'') with a falling tone means "love". These spellings, which follow specific [[Spelling in Gwoyeu Romatzyh#Tonal rules|rules]], indicate the tones while retaining the pronunciation of the syllable ''ai''. Chao claimed that, because GR embeds the tone of each syllable in its spelling,"The common [foreign] attitude of treating the tone as an [[epiphenomenon]] on top of the solid sounds—consonants and vowels—is to the Chinese mind quite unintelligible..." Chao and Yang(1947):xv. it may [[#Language learning|help students to master Chinese tones]]. One study of GR, however, found the opposite to be true."The results clearly indicated that GR did not lead to significantly greater accuracy in tonal production. Indeed, the use of GR reflected slightly lower rates of tonal production accuracy for native speakers of both American English and Japanese." McGinnis(1997). GR uses a complicated system of tonal spelling that obscures the basic relationship between spelling and tone; for example, the difference between tones 1 and 2 is variously indicated as ''mha'' vs. ''ma'', ''ching'' vs. ''chyng'', ''chang'' vs. ''charng'', etc. Although tonal spelling has been adopted as part of the normal romanization of a number of Asian languages (e.g. [[Hmong language|Hmong]]), all such systems indicate different tones in a simple and consistent fashion by adding letters to the end of a syllable (e.g. in Hmong, ''-b'' indicates high tone, ''-s'' indicates low tone, ''-j'' indicates high-falling tone, etc.). In 1928 China adopted GR as the nation's official romanization system.Kratochvíl(1968):169 GR was used to indicate pronunciations in dictionaries of the National (Mandarin-based) Language. Its proponents hoped one day to establish it as a writing system for a reformed Chinese script. But despite support from a small number of trained linguists in China and overseas, GR met with public indifference and even hostility due to its complexity.For a detailed account of the historical background, see {{cite web | author = John DeFrancis | url= http://www.pinyin.info/readings/texts/DeFr1950.html | title= Chapter 4 of DeFrancis(1950) | publisher = pinyin.info | accessdate=2007-02-27}} Another obstacle preventing its widespread adoption was its narrow basis on the Beijing dialect, in a period lacking a strong centralized government to enforce its use. Eventually GR lost ground to [[Pinyin]] and other later romanization systems. However, its influence is still evident, as several of the principles introduced by its creators have been used in romanization systems that followed it. Its pattern of tone spelling was retained in the standard spelling of the Chinese province of [[Shaanxi]] ''(shǎnxī, 陝西),'' which cannot be distinguished from [[Shanxi]] ''(shānxī, 山西)'' when written in pinyin without diacritics. ==History== [[File:Linyutang.jpg|thumb|left|[[Lin Yutang]], who first proposed tonal spelling]] [[#Tonal modifications|Tonal spelling]], Gwoyeu Romatzyh's most distinctive feature, was first suggested to Y.R. Chao by [[Lin Yutang]]."Without disclaiming responsibility, as a very active member of the Committee on Unification, for the merits and defects of the system, I must give credit to my colleague Lin Yutang for the idea of varying the spelling to indicate difference in tone." Chao(1948):11 footnote.For the historical background see {{cite web | author = John DeFrancis | url= http://www.pinyin.info/readings/texts/DeFr1950.html | title= One State, One People, One Language | publisher = Pinyin.info | accessdate=2007-02-27}} (Chapter 4 of DeFrancis[1950]). By 1922 Chao had already established the main principles of GR.DeFrancis(1950): Ch 4, footnotes 43 and 46. The details of the system were developed in 1925–1926 by a group of five linguists, led by Chao and including Lin, under the auspices of the [[Mandarin Promotion Council|Preparatory Commission for the Unification of the National Language]].DeFrancis(1950): 74 In 1928 GR was officially adopted by the government. GR was intended to be used alongside the existing [[Zhuyin|''Juhin'' (''Zhùyīn'')]] phonetic symbols: hence the alternative name for GR, "Second Pattern of the National Alphabet."{{lang|cmn-Hans|国音字母第二式}} / ''Gwoin Tzyhmuu Dihell Shyh'' / ''Guóyīn Zìmǔ Dì'èr Shì'': see Simon, W.(1947):Table X, lxxi. Both systems were used to indicate the revised standard of pronunciation in the new official ''Vocabulary of National Pronunciation for Everyday Use'' of 1932.{{lang|cmn-Hans|国音常用字汇}} / ''Gwoin Charngyonq Tzyhhuey'' / ''Guóyīn Chángyòng Zìhuì'': see Chao(1948):11. The designers of GR had greater ambitions: their aim was complete reform of the script, using GR as a practical system of writing."While the official position was that it was to be used whenever Chinese was to be spelled in Latin letters, such as in dealing with foreigners, those who devised the system, of whom I was one, had in our minds the design of a practical system of writing." Chao(1968c) [[File:Zhao Yuanren.jpg|thumb|right|[[Yuen Ren Chao]], the chief designer of GR, as a young man (c. 1916)]] In the 1930s two shortlived attempts were made to teach GR to railway workers and peasants in [[Henan|Hénán]] and [[Shandong|Shāndōng]] provinces.DeFrancis(1950): 77–78 Support for GR, being confined to a small number of trained linguists and Sinologists, "was distinguished more for its quality than its quantity."DeFrancis(1950): 75. The supporters included [[Qian Xuantong]] and [[Luo Changpei]] in China and [[Walter Simon (sinologist)|Walter Simon]] in England. During this period GR faced increasing hostility because of the complexity of its tonal spelling. Conversely, Sinologist [[Bernhard Karlgren]] criticised GR for its lack of phonetic rigour."[GR] is based on a series of very fatal phonetic lies, and for this reason it will be very difficult to learn, and consequently impractical." Karlgren(1928):20 Ultimately, like the rival (toneless) system [[Latinxua Sinwenz]], GR failed to gain widespread support, principally because the "National" language was too narrowly based on [[Beijing dialect|Beijing speech]]:DeFrancis(1950):76 "a sufficiently precise and strong language norm had not yet become a reality in China".Kratochvíl(1968):169. A vestigial use of GR can be seen in the official spelling of the first syllable of ''Shaanxi'' for [[Shaanxi|Shǎnxī]] (陝西) province, to distinguish it from [[Shanxi|Shānxī]] (山西) province, particularly in foreign-language text where the tone marks are often omitted.{{Cite web |url=http://www.thepaper.cn/newsDetail_forward_1495089 |title=涨知识｜陕西为什么拼作Shaanxi，而不是Shanxi_中国政库_澎湃新闻-The Paper |website=www.thepaper.cn |access-date=2017-12-19}} Some prominent Chinese have used GR to transliterate their names: for example the mathematician [[Shiing-Shen Chern]].Neither Chao nor Lin, however, followed this practice. The romanization system was changed by the government of the [[People's Republic of China]] in 1958 to the current system used now in the country, and other foreign and international institutions, like the [[United Nations]], the [[Library of Congress]], the [[International Organization for Standardization]], and is widely used to teach [[Mandarin Chinese]] to foreign students: [[Hanyu Pinyin]]. Meanwhile, in the [[Republic of China]] (Taiwan), GR survived until the 1970s as a pronunciation aid in monolingual dictionaries such as ''Gwoyeu Tsyrdean [Guóyǔ Cídiǎn]'' and ''Tsyrhuey [Cíhuì]'',For an account of the phonetization of Chinese in Taiwan, see Chen(1999):189 but was officially replaced in 1986 by a modified form known as [[Mandarin Phonetic Symbols II]].{{cite web | author = Wi-vun Taiffalo Chiung | url=http://www.de-han.org/pehoeji/lomaji/4.htm | title= Romanization and Language Planning in Taiwan | publisher = Center for Thoat-Han Studies | accessdate=2007-02-27}} This is an online version of Chiung(2001). The [[Warring States period]] State of [[Wey (state)|Wey]] ({{zh|t=衛|oc=}}) is often spelled as such to distinguish it from the more prominent state {{zh|t=魏}}, which are both pronounced Wèi in Mandarin, but in [[Old Chinese]] it was probably /*ɢʷat-s/ and /*N-qʰuj-s/, respectively. ==Description== {{main article|Spelling in Gwoyeu Romatzyh}} :''Note:'' In this section the word "tone" is abbreviated as "T": thus T1 stands for Tone 1 (first tone), etc. To assist readers unfamiliar with GR, Pinyin equivalents have been added in brackets. ===Basic forms (Tone 1)=== {{IPA notice}} An important feature of GR, adopted from other precursors and later also adopted by [[Pinyin]], is the use of contrasting [[voice (phonetics)|unvoiced/voiced]] pairs of consonants from Latin to represent [[aspiration (phonetics)|aspirated and unaspirated]] sounds in Chinese.See Chao(1948):19–24 and Chao(1968a):20–25 for tables and fuller discussion. Complete tables of GR initials and finals are also given in [[Spelling in Gwoyeu Romatzyh#Basic forms]]. For example ''b'' and ''p'' represent {{IPA|/p/}} and {{IPA|/pʰ/}} (''p'' and ''p‘'' in Wade). Another distinctive feature of GR is the use of ''j, ch,'' and ''sh'' to represent two different series of sounds. When followed by ''i'' these letters correspond to the [[alveolo-palatal consonant|alveolo-palatal]] sounds (Pinyin ''j, q,'' and ''x''); otherwise they correspond to the [[retroflex consonant|retroflex]] sounds (Pinyin ''zh, ch,'' and ''sh''). Readers used to Pinyin need to pay particular attention to these spellings: for example, GR ''ju, jiu,'' and ''jiou'' correspond to Pinyin ''zhu, ju,'' and ''jiu'' respectively.See [[Spelling in Gwoyeu Romatzyh#Pinyin comparison: basic forms|Spelling in Gwoyeu Romatzyh]] for a table showing the correspondence of GR and Pinyin forms. GR orthography has these additional notable features: *''iu'' represents the [[close front rounded vowel]] {{IPA|/y/}} spelled ''ü'' or in many cases simply ''u'' in Pinyin. *Final ''-y'' represents the {{IPA-cmn|ɨ|}} [[allophone]] of ''i'': GR ''shy'' and ''sy'' correspond to Pinyin ''shi'' and ''si'' respectively. *''el'' corresponds to Pinyin ''er'' (''-r'' being reserved to indicate Tone2). The most important use of ''-(e)l'' is as a [[R-colored vowel|rhotacization]] suffix, as in ''ideal'' = ''i dean'' + ''-(e)l'', "a little" (yìdiǎnr). *A number of frequently occurring [[morpheme]]s have abbreviated spellings in GR. The commonest of these are: ''-g'' (-ge), ''-j'' (-zhe), ''-m'' (-me), ''sh'' (shi) and ''-tz'' (-zi).These and other abbreviations are listed in Chao(1968a):xxx. ===Tonal modifications=== By default, the basic GR spelling described above is used for Tone1 syllables. The basic form is then modified to indicate tones 2, 3 and 4.The rules are given, though in a different form, in Chao (1948): 28–30 (synopsis p 336) and Chao (1968a): 29–30 (synopsis p 847). See also Table IX in Simon, W.(1947):lviii. This is accomplished in one of three ways: *'''either''' a vowel is changed to another vowel resembling it in sound (''i'' to ''y'', for example, or ''u'' to ''w'') *'''or''' a letter is doubled *'''or''' a silent letter (''r'' or ''h'') is added after the vowel. Wherever possible the concise first method is used. The following rules of thumb cover most cases.See [[Spelling in Gwoyeu Romatzyh#Tonal rules]] for a more thorough discussion. '''Tone 1 (basic form)''' :''shiue, chuan, chang, hai, bau'' (xuē, chuān, chāng, hāi, bāo) '''Tone 2: i/u → y/w; or add -r''' :''shyue, chwan, charng, hair, baur'' (xué, chuán, cháng, hái, báo) '''Tone 3: i/u → e/o; or double vowel''' :''sheue, choan, chaang, hae, bao'' (xuě, chuǎn, chǎng, hǎi, bǎo) '''Tone 4: change/double final letter; or add -h''' :''shiueh, chuann, chanq, hay, baw'' (xuè, chuàn, chàng, hài, bào) '''Neutral tone: precede with a dot (full stop)''' :''perng.yeou, dih.fang'' (péngyou, dìfang). '''Exception''' Syllables with an initial [[sonorant]] (''l-/m-/n-/r-'') use the basic form for T2 rather than T1. In these syllables the (rarer) T1 is marked with ''-h-'' as the second letter. For example ''mha'' is T1 (mā), whereas ''ma'' is T2 (má).Examples: (T1) ''Mha.mha'' ({{lang|cmn-Hans|妈妈}} ''Māma''), "Mum"; (T2) ''mamuh'' ({{lang|cmn-Hani|麻木}} ''mámù''), "numb". T3 and T4 are regular: ''maa'' (''mǎ'') and ''mah'' (''mà''). ==Compounds as words== An important principle of GR is that syllables which form words should be written together. This strikes speakers of European languages as obvious; but in Chinese the concept of "word" is not easy to pin down. The basic unit of speech is popularly thought to be the monosyllable represented by a [[Written Chinese#Chinese characters (2)|character]] ({{lang|cmn-Hani|字}} ''tzyh'', ''zì''), which in most cases represents a meaningful syllable or [[morpheme]],Chao calls the character the "sociological word", since it is the unit by which children's vocabulary is measured, journalists are paid and telegrams charged for. Chao(1968a): 136. a smaller unit than the "linguistic word".For thorough discussions, see Chao(1968a): 138–143 and Kratochvíl(1968):89–99. Characters are written and printed with no spaces between words; yet in practice most [[Chinese language#Grammar and morphology|Chinese words]] consist of two-syllable compounds, and it was Chao's bold innovation in 1922 to reflect this in GR [[orthography]] by grouping the appropriate syllables together into words.DeFrancis(1950): Ch 4, note 46. This represented a radical departure from hyphenated Wade–Giles forms such as ''Kuo2-yü3 Lo2-ma3-tzu4'' (the Wade spelling of GR). ==Use in published texts== Chao used GR in four influential works: *''[[Concise Dictionary of Spoken Chinese]]'' (in collaboration with [[Yang Lien-sheng|Lien Sheng Yang]]) (1947) *''Mandarin Primer''Recordings, including online excerpts, of this lively, though now rather dated, text are available from {{cite web | author = Yuen Ren Chao | url= http://www.folkways.si.edu/search/AlbumDetails.aspx?ID=1407# | title= Mandarin Primer | publisher = Smithsonian Folkways Recordings | accessdate=2007-02-27| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051027101123/http://www.folkways.si.edu/search/AlbumDetails.aspx?ID=1407| archivedate = October 27, 2005}}. (1948) :This course was originally used in the [[Army Specialized Training Program]] at the [[Harvard University|Harvard]] School for Overseas Administration in 1943–1944 and subsequently in civilian courses.Chao(1948):v. *''A Grammar of Spoken Chinese''"The most comprehensive grammar of MSC [Modern Standard Chinese] in English." Kratochvíl(1968):187. (1968a) *
''Readings in Sayable Chinese''Cassette recordings of this text are available from various online sources. (1968b) [[[#Example|Extract]]]
"Sayable" in this context means colloquial,Chao describes the colloquial Chinese heard on the street as "sayable, even if sometimes unspeakable". (Chao 1968b): I,vi) as opposed to the [[vernacular Chinese]] (''bairhuah'', Pinyin ''báihuà'') style often read by students. ''Readings in Sayable Chinese'' was written "to supply the advanced student of spoken Chinese with reading matter which he can actually use in his speech."Chao(1968b): I,iv It consists of three volumes of Chinese text with facing GR romanization.{{cite web | author = Yuen Ren Chao | url= http://www.pinyin.info/readings/sayable_chinese.html | title= Readings in Sayable Chinese: table of contents | publisher = pinyin.info | accessdate=2007-03-02}} They contain some lively recorded dialogues, "Fragments of an autobiography," two plays and a translation of [[Lewis Carroll]]'s ''[[Through the Looking-Glass]] (Tzoou daw Jinqtz lii)''.{{lang|cmn-Hant|走到鏡子裡跟阿麗思看見裡頭有些什麼}} ''Tzoou daw Jinqtz lii gen Alihsy Kannjiann Liitou Yeou Shie Sherme / Zǒu dào jìngzili gēn Ālìsī kànjian lǐtou yǒu xiē shénme''. Two extracts from ''Tzoou daw Jinqtz lii'' with facing translations can be read online.The extracts comprise Alice's conversations with Tweedledum and Tweedledee ({{cite web | author = Lewis Carroll [Y.R. Chao trans.] | url= http://home.iprimus.com.au/richwarm/gr/tweedle.htm | title= Yuen Ren Chao in Wonderland | publisher = Richard Warmington | accessdate=2007-03-12}}) and Humpty Dumpty ({{cite web | author = Lewis Carroll [Y.R. Chao trans.] | url= http://pinyin.info/readings/alice/humpty_dumpty_chinese.html | title= Humpty Dumpty in Mandarin Chinese | publisher = Pinyin.info | accessdate=2007-03-15}}). The second webpage also includes a version of the text in Pinyin. In 1942 [[Walter Simon (sinologist)|Walter Simon]] introduced GR to English-speaking sinologists in a special pamphlet, ''The New Official Chinese Latin Script''. Over the remainder of the 1940s he published a series of textbooks and readers,See the [[Walter Simon (sinologist)|complete list]] of these publications. as well as a Chinese-English Dictionary, all using GR. His son Harry Simon later went on to use GR in scholarly papers on Chinese linguistics.See for example Simon, H.F.(1958). In 1960 Y.C. Liu, a colleague of Walter Simon's at [[SOAS]], published ''Fifty Chinese Stories''. These selections from [[Chinese classic texts|classical texts]] were presented in both [[classical Chinese|classical]] and modern Chinese,"[The book's] primary aim is to introduce students to the Classical style through the medium of the modern spoken language." Liu (1960):xii (Introduction by W. Simon) together with GR romanizations and [[Romanization of Japanese|romanized Japanese]] versions prepared by Simon (by that time Professor [[Emeritus]] of Chinese in the [[University of London]]). [[Lin Yutang]]'s ''[[Chinese-English Dictionary of Modern Usage]]'' (1972) incorporated a number of innovative features, one of which was a simplified version of GR."In the original edition, 'Guoryuu Romatzyh' ({{lang|cmn-Hant|國語羅馬字}}) was used as the scheme for romanization." Another feature was an "Instant Index System": "an invention by Lin Yutang with the intention of providing a simple and unambiguous rule to call up any given Chinese character ... [T]his index system has not been widely used since its inception." {{cite web | author = Lin Yutang | url = http://humanum.arts.cuhk.edu.hk/Lexis/Lindict/lyt-fl.htm | title = Chinese-English Dictionary of Modern Usage (Online Version) | publisher = Chinese University of Hong Kong | accessdate=2007-03-27}}Ching(1975). Lin eliminated most of the spelling rules requiring substitution of vowels, as can be seen from his spelling ''Guoryuu Romatzyh'', in which the regular [[#T2Rule|''-r'' is used for T2]] and a [[#T3Rule|doubled vowel for T3]]. The first 3 issues of the ''Shin Tarng'' magazine (which would be ''Xīn Táng'' in Pinyin; published in 1982-1989) used a Simplified Romanisation ({{lang|cmn-Hant|簡化羅馬字}} {{lang|cmn-Latn|Jiannhuah Rormaatzyh}}) based on Gwoyeu Romatzyh; the fourth edition, entitled Xin Talng, used Pinyin with Gwoyeu Romatzyh-like tone marking.[http://www.pinyin.info/readings/xin_tang/ Xin Tang: a journal of romanized Mandarin] ==Language learning== Chao believed that the benefit of GR was to make tonal differences more salient to learners: {{cquote|[GR] makes the spelling more complicated, but gives an ''individuality to the physiognomy of words'', with which it is possible to associate meaning ... [A]s an instrument of teaching, tonal spelling has proved in practice to be a most powerful aid in enabling the student to grasp the material with precision and clearness.Chao(1948):11 (emphasis added).}} For example, it may be easier to memorize the difference between GR ''Beeijing'' (the city) and ''beyjiing'' ("background") than the Pinyin versions ''Běijīng'' and ''bèijǐng'', where the tones seem to be almost an afterthought. One study conducted at the [[University of Oregon]] in 1991–1993, compared the results of using Pinyin and GR in teaching elementary level Chinese to two matched groups of students, and concluded that "GR did not lead to significantly greater accuracy in tonal production."McGinnis(1997) GR continues to be used by some teachers of Chinese. In 2000, the Princeton ''Chinese Primer'' series was published in both GR and Pinyin versions.Ch'en et al.(2000) ==Example== Here is an extract from Y.R. Chao's [[#sayable|''Sayable Chinese'']]. The topic is scholarly ("What is Sinology?"), but the style colloquial. The tonal spelling markers or "clues" are again highlighted using the same [[#Tonal modifications|color-coding scheme]] as above. Versions in [[#chin|Chinese characters]], [[#pin|Pinyin]] and [[#eng|English]] are given below the GR text. {|class="wikitable" |- !Writing system !Text |- |Gwoyeu Romatzyh |"Hannshyue" .de mingcheng duey Jonggwo yeou idean butzuenjinq .de yihwey. Woo.men tingshuo yeou "Yinnduhshyue", "Aijyishyue", "Hannshyue", erl meiyeou tingshuo yeou "Shilahshyue", "Luomaashyue", genq meiyeou tingshuo yeou "Inggwoshyue", "Meeigwoshyue". "Hannshyue" jeyg mingcheng wanchyuan beaushyh Ou-Meei shyuejee duey nahshie yiijing chernluen de guulao-gwojia de wenhuah de i-joong chingkann de tayduh.Extract from ''Her Wey Hannshyue? (Hé wèi Hànxué?)'' by Jou Faagau (Zhōu Fǎgāo). '''Habetrot''' (''Habitrot'', ''Habtrot'' and ''Habbitrot'') is a figure in [[folklore]] of the [[Anglo-Scottish border|Border counties]]<ref name=henderson1>''Notes on the folk-lore of the northern counties of England and the borders'', William Henderson, Longmans, Green, 1866. pp. 4-5</ref><ref name=henderson2>''Notes on the folk-lore of the northern counties of England and the borders'', William Henderson, Longmans, Green, 1866. pp. 221-226</ref> of [[Northumbria|Northern England]]<ref name=henderson1/><ref name=rose>''Spirits, fairies, gnomes, and goblins: an encyclopedia of the little people'', Carol Rose, ABC-CLIO, 1996, 0874368111, 9780874368116. Page. 141</ref> and [[Scottish Borders|Lowland Scotland]]<ref name=henderson1/><ref name=rose/> associated with [[spinning (textiles)|spinning]] and the spinning wheel.<ref name=henderson1/><ref name=henderson2/><ref name=comp>''A companion to the fairy tale'', Hilda Ellis Davidson, Anna Chaudhri, DS Brewer, 2006, {{ISBN|1-84384-081-2}}, {{ISBN|978-1-84384-081-7}}. page. 107</ref> A well known folktale to feature this character was recorded in [[Selkirkshire]]<ref name=henderson2/><ref name=comp/> and featured her along with two other spinsters, who in compliment to Habetrot's deformed lips feature a splayed foot and a flat thumb respectively. This tale is related to tales found in countries such as Germany (such as [[The Three Spinners]]) and Norway ([[The Three Aunts]]).<ref name=comp/>
According to the folklore of the borders it was considered unlucky to step upon "unchristened ground" (the graves of stillborn or unbaptised children) and any who did were said to catch "grave-merels" (or "grave-scab") an illness that causes difficulty of breathing and trembling limbs as well as the burning of the skin as if touched by a hot iron.<ref name=henderson1/> The only way for this to be relieved was for the unfortunate to wear a sack made from linen grown in a field using manure from a farmyard that has not been disturbed for forty years, spun by ''Habetrot'', bleached by an honest bleacher in an honest miller's [[milldam]] and sewed by an honest tailor.<ref name=henderson1/>
==References== {{Reflist}} * [[Katharine Mary Briggs|Katharine Briggs]], ''An Encyclopedia of Fairies, Hobgoblins, Brownies, Bogies, and Other Supernatural Creatures,'' "Habetrot", pp213-216 {{ISBN|0-394-73467-X}}.
==External links== * [http://www.allfiberarts.com/library/poetry/blhabetrot-f.htm Habetrot and the Scantlie Mab (folktale)] {{Fairies}} [[Category:Northumbrian folklore]] [[Category:Northumbrian folkloric beings]] [[Category:Scottish folklore]] [[Category:English legendary creatures]] [[Category:Textiles in mythology and folklore]]
{{legendary-creature-stub}}

{{legal status}} '''Immigration law''' refers to the national [[statute]]s, [[Primary and secondary legislation|regulations]], and [[Precedent|legal precedents]] governing [[immigration]] into and [[deportation]] from a [[country]]. Strictly speaking, it is distinct from other matters such as [[naturalization]] and [[citizenship]], although they are often conflated. Immigration laws vary around the world, as well as according to the [[Society|social]] and [[political climate]] of the times, as acceptance of immigrants sways from the widely inclusive to the deeply [[Nationalism|nationalist]] and [[Isolationism|isolationist]]. Countries frequently maintain laws which regulate both the rights of entry and exit as well as internal rights, such as the duration of stay, [[freedom of movement]], and the right to participate in [[commerce]] or [[government]].
National laws regarding the immigration of citizens of that country are regulated by [[international law]]. The [[United Nations|United Nations']] [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] mandates<ref>art 12(4)</ref> that all countries allow entry to their own citizens.
==Control measures== To control immigration, many countries set up customs at entry points. Some common location for entry points are airports and roads near the border. At the customs department, [[travel document]]s are inspected. Some required documents are a [[passport]], an [[Carte Jaune|international certificate of vaccination]] and an [[onward ticket]]. Sometimes travelers are also required to declare or register the amount of money they are carrying.

A limit on number of Tier 2 migrants per year coming from outside the country was introduced by new government which makes it more difficult to find an employer willing to sponsor the visa if applying from outside the UK. | (practically not available since April 2011) [[Tier 1 General]] – settlement (ILR) after 5 years. A limit on 1000 Tier 1 migrants per year introduced by new government. Besides that the migration legislation changes on average every six months which makes Britain not attractive for skilled migrants looking for a second nationality. | [[Tier 1 Entrepreneur]] | [[Tier 1 Investor]] | There is no specific category here but it is easier for universities (as opposed to businesses) to acquire a Tier 2 sponsorship licence. | ILR is provided after 5 years in marriage or partnership and living in the country. | British citizenship can be obtained as a right for anybody who was born in the UK before 1983. It is also available as of right for people of whom one parent is a British citizen otherwise than by descent".<ref>British Nationality Act 1981, s2(1)(a), subject to s14</ref> All other classes of British Nationality do not confer right of abode in the UK to the holder. | [[Tier4]] Full-time students at university education are allowed to work up to 20 hours a week. Others are allowed to work up to 10 hours per week. After 10 years of continuous presence in the country on residential visas ILR is provided. {{Other people|John Valentine}} {{Infobox professional wrestler |name = Johnny Valentine |image = |caption = |birth_name = John Theodore Wisniski |names = Johnny Valentine
The Big O |height = {{height|ft=6|in=4}} |weight = {{convert|255|lb|kg st|abbr=on}} |birth_date = {{Birth date|1928|9|22}} |birth_place = [[Maple Valley, Washington]], [[United States]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|2001|4|24|1928|9|22}} |death_place = [[River Oaks, Texas]], [[United States]] |billed = |trainer = |debut = 1947 |retired = 1975 }} '''John Theodore Wisniski'''{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/may/09/local/me-61326|title=Johnny Valentine; Plane Crash Cut Short Pro Wrestler's Career|accessdate=2009-03-21|date=2001-05-09|work= Los Angeles Times|location=Los Angeles}} (September 22, 1928 – April 24, 2001), better known by his ring name '''Johnny Valentine''', was an [[United States|American]] [[professional wrestling|professional wrestler]] with a career spanning almost three decades. He has been inducted into four halls of fame for his achievements in wrestling. Wisniski is the father of professional wrestler [[Greg Valentine|Greg "The Hammer" Valentine]]. He held numerous regional titles, including the NWA United States Heavyweight Championship. He had long running rivalries with [[Bobo Brazil]], [[Pat O'Connor (wrestler)|Pat O'Connor]], [[Buddy Rogers (wrestler)|Buddy Rogers]], [[Antonino Rocca|Antonio Rocca]], [[Lou Thesz]], [[Harley Race]], [[Ed Farhat|The Sheik]], [[Wahoo McDaniel]], [[Fritz von Erich]], [[Bruno Sammartino]], [[Johnny Powers (wrestler)|Johnny Powers]], [[Antonio Inoki]] and [[Jack Brisco|Jack]] & [[Gerald Brisco|Jerry Brisco]]. He alternated between being a [[Heel (professional wrestling)|villain]] and a hero (babyface) during the Golden Era in the 1940s through 1960s of wrestling.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingBiosV/valentine_obit-can.html|title=Johnny Valentine passes away|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|author=Molinaro, John F.|accessdate=2009-01-05|date=April 24, 2001}} In 1975, he was injured in a plane crash; he suffered a broken back and was forced to retire from wrestling. He worked briefly as a [[Manager (professional wrestling)|manager]] before retiring altogether. He suffered from several health problems during his retirement, which worsened considerably after a fall in 2000. He died the following year. ==Professional wrestling career== [[File:Johnny Valentine vs. NWA world wrestling champion Dory Funk Jr. at Maple Leaf Gardens in Toronto on February 11, 1973.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Valentine vs. [[Dory Funk Jr.]] in 1973]] Wisniski debuted as a professional wrestler in 1947, wrestling Karl Nowena in [[Buenos Aires]]. In order to make the matches as believable as possible Wisniski insisted the men he faced in the ring hit him as hard as possible. From that he earned a strong reputation as being a very tough man. On New Year's Day, 1950, [[Buddy Rogers (wrestler)|Buddy Rogers]] defeated Wisniski in the finals of a United States title tournament. He also competed in the NWA's Capitol Wrestling territory. Jerry Graham, who was a co-holder of the Northeast version of the [[WWF United States Tag Team Championship|NWA United States Tag Team Championship]], selected Wisniski in November 1959 to take over the title from Graham's injured partner. They were beaten for the title belts the following April, but Wisniski took on a new partner, Buddy Rogers, to regain the championship by defeating [[The Fabulous Kangaroos]] on November 19, 1960. Wisniski's rivalry with the Kangaroos continued, as the Kangaroos regained the belts in a rematch one week later. Wisniski went over one year without holding a championship before teaming with a new partner, this time Bob Ellis, to defeat the Kangaroos and take back the championship. Wisniski & Ellis lost the belts to Buddy Rogers & Handsome Johnny Barend in a match where Arnold Skoaland subbed for Ellis, but the belts were still up, on Washington, DC TV. Rogers & Barend then defeated the real team of Wisniski & Ellis 2 pins to 1 in a main event at Madison Square Garden. In Toronto, Wisniski and three different partners won the International Tag Team title during 1963. Wisniski left the territory without [[List of professional wrestling terms#D|dropping]] the title. He wrestled in Japan in the mid-1960s and had a series of matches against Antonio Inoki. Those matches are regarded as the bouts that helped build Inoki into an elite wrestler in Japan, as Valentine was the highest-profile foreign wrestler Inoki had ever faced at the time. Valentine [[List of professional wrestling terms#P|put over]] Inoki in the matches, [[List of professional wrestling terms#D|dropping]] the Toronto version of the [[NWA United States Heavyweight Championship (Toronto version)|NWA United States Heavyweight Championship]] to him catapulting Inoki's career in the process.{{cite book|page=128|first=Dave|last=Meltzer|title=Tributes II: Remembering More of the World's Greatest Professional Wrestlers|year=2004|publisher=Sports Publishing LLC|isbn=1-58261-817-8}} Wisniski also continued to wrestle in the former Capitol Wrestling territory, which had since been renamed the [[World Wrestling Entertainment|World Wide Wrestling Federation]]. While there, he had one last reign with what was then known as the [[WWWF United States Tag Team Championship]], as he teamed with [[Antonio Pugliese|Tony Parisi]] to hold the belts for seven months in 1966. Wisniski later [[Turn (professional wrestling)|turned]] on Parisi, however. This ignited a brief feud with [[Bruno Sammartino]], who was billed as Parisi's cousin. Because Wisniski was also wrestling in Texas at the same time, he got only sporadic main event matches against Sammartino during this feud.{{cite book|page=131|first=Dave|last=Meltzer|title=Tributes II: Remembering More of the World's Greatest Professional Wrestlers|year=2004|publisher=Sports Publishing LLC|isbn=1-58261-817-8}} Wisniski then moved on to the [[Florida]] territory, where he won the [[NWA Florida Heavyweight Championship]] three times. In [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], he defeated [[Tim Woods]] for the NWA Georgia Heavyweight title, on May 10, 1968, and repeated his win in a match against Doug Gilbert (not to be confused with the [[Doug Gilbert]] who was not yet born) to retake the title. In Missouri, Wisniski competed for the Missouri Heavyweight Championship in a tournament to determine the inaugural champion. He defeated [[Baron von Raschke]] before withdrawing from the tournament due to focus his efforts on the [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship]]. After [[Harley Race]] won the tournament and the title belt, Valentine defeated him to win the championship on January 19, 1973. He dropped the belt to [[Terry Funk]] the following month. Because Funk used a chair as a weapon in front of the referee, fans demanded a rematch. Valentine was unable to compete due to heart problems, however, so [[Gene Kiniski]] took his place and won the belt from Funk.{{cite web|title=History of the Missouri State Championship|first=Roger|last=Deem|url=http://www.stlwrestlingfromthechase.com/mobelt.htm|publisher=St. Louis Wrestling from the Chase|accessdate=2009-03-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080408195415/http://www.stlwrestlingfromthechase.com/mobelt.htm|archivedate=2008-04-08|df=}}{{cite book|title=Wrestling at the Chase: The Inside Story of Sam Muchnick and the Legends of Professional Wrestling|first=Larry|last=Matysik|authorlink=Larry Matysik|page=23|publisher=ECW Press|year=2003|isbn=1-55022-684-3}} In October 1972, Wisniski defeated [[Jacques Rougeau]] for the International Heavyweight Championship, but was stripped of the title in January 1973, after he no-showed the rematch. In the [[National Wrestling Federation]], Wisniski defeated [[Johnny Powers (wrestler)|Johnny Powers]] for the [[NWF North American Heavyweight Championship]] on September 1, 1972. Powers beat Wisniski for the title in October, but Wisniski won the title again from [[Abdullah the Butcher]] on October 19. He was stripped of the title following a match with Johnny Powers. On November 23, he captured the title from Powers, but lost it again in January. In the [[Japan Wrestling Association]], Wisniski won the International Tag Team title on February 22, 1973, and then the [[United National Heavyweight Championship]] on March 2. He lost the Tag title on March 6, and the United Heavyweight title on March 8. Back in the National Wrestling Federation, in August 1973, Wisniski beat Jacques Rougeau, Sr. to win the North American Heavyweight Championship. He lost it to Johnny Powers in late 1973. In [[Mid-Atlantic Championship Wrestling]], Wisniski was awarded the Mid Atlantic Heavyweight Championship in January 1974, after [[Jerry Brisco]] left to work in [[Japan]]. [[Bearcat Wright]] defeated Wisniski in a boxing match to win the title on May 13, 1974. He won the championship from Sonny King on November 4, and won the United States Heavyweight Championship on July 4, 1975. After Wisniski was paralyzed in a plane crash, he remained active in professional wrestling as a [[Manager (professional wrestling)|manager]] in [[Paul Boesch]]'s Texas-based promotion. From his wheelchair, Wisniski managed [[Dale Hey]], who competed as Dale Valentine in a storyline that saw the two promoted as brothers. The storyline did not last long, however.{{cite book|page=124|first=Dave|last=Meltzer|title=Tributes II: Remembering More of the World's Greatest Professional Wrestlers|year=2004|publisher=Sports Publishing LLC|isbn=1-58261-817-8}} ==Personal life== Wisniski was originally from [[Maple Valley, Washington]]. He is said to have come from a dysfunctional family. He was a devout Christian for many years.{{cite web|last=Molinaro|first=John F.|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingBiosV/valentine_00dec21-can.html|title=Johnny Valentine's fight for life|accessdate=2009-03-22|date=2000-12-21|work=Slam! Wrestling}} He was married in the early 1950s and the marriage lasted 20 years until they divorced. He was later married to a woman named Sharon, who worked across the street from his apartment in the mid 1970s when they met. She later visited John as he was recovering in hospital from his 1975 plane crash. Some time later the relationship ended as he didn't want her to see him in his condition. Years later while on braces and crutches he managed to drive around her neighbourhood for hours until he found her house. As he slowly walked to the front door Sharon`s daughter announced to Sharon that Johnny Valentine was in front of their home. Sharon having been ill refused to go to the door and hid. Wisniski insisted he wouldn't leave until he saw her. When she finally came to the door he asked her to marry him and she accepted. Following John`s death, Sharon planned to write a book titled ''A Never Ending Love Story of a Wrestler and His Wife'' about their life together.{{cite web|title=Sharon Valentine talks about her love for Johnny Valentine|publisher=SLAM! Sadly ill health and her eventual death prevented the release. Wrestling|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingBiosV/valentine_sharon-can.html|accessdate=2009-03-23|first=John M.|last=Molinaro|date=2001-06-21}} He also had a son from a long ago previous relationship, [[Greg Valentine]], who has wrestled professionally since 1970 and is best known as Greg "The Hammer" Valentine. [[Ric Flair]], who wrestled with Wisniski, has described him as a quiet person who kept to himself. He was also known for making his demands clear to employers and not backing down,{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingBiosV/valentine_memories-can.html|title=Flair, friends remember Johnny Valentine|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|date=2001-04-24|first=Greg|last=Oliver|accessdate=2009-03-23}} and many stories continue to circulate about practical jokes, or [[List of professional wrestling terms#R|ribs]], that he played on his fellow wrestlers.{{cite web|publisher=Mid-Atlantic Gateway|title=Interview: Tommy Young - Part 3|url=http://www.midatlanticgateway.com/Resource_Center/interviews/young/tommy_young03.htm|accessdate=2009-03-24|date=2003-06-10}} On October 4, 1975, Wisniski was in a [[airplane|private airplane]] {{cite web|last=Slagle|first=Steve|url=http://www.wrestlingmuseum.com/pages/wrestlers/johnnyvalentine2.html |title=Johnny Valentine|accessdate=2009-03-21|work=Professional Wrestling Online Museum}} (a twin-engined Cessna 310{{cite web |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingFlair/planecrash-can.html|title=The plane crash that changed wrestling. It's been 25 years since Valentine, Flair, Woods, Crockett went down|accessdate=2009-03-22|author=John F. Molinaro|date= 2000-12-28|format= ymd|work= Slam! Sports}}) with [[Ric Flair]], [[David Crockett (wrestling)|David Crockett]], [[Bob Bruggers]], and [[Tim Woods]].{{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/j/johnny-valentine.html|title= Wrestler Profiles|accessdate=2009-03-21|work=Online World of Wrestling Wrestler Profiles}} Because of the weight of the passengers, the pilot realized that he could not take off without reducing the amount of [[aircraft fuel|fuel]] the plane was carrying. Part way through the flight, the aircraft ran out of fuel and crashed near [[Wilmington, North Carolina]].{{cite web |url=http://www.pwhf.org/halloffamers/bios/valentine.asp |title=Johnny Valentine |accessdate=2009-03-21 |author=Chris Sokol |author2=Greg Oliver |year=2006 |work=Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090408045943/http://www.pwhf.org/halloffamers/bios/valentine.asp |archivedate=2009-04-08 |df= }} The crash broke Flair's back, Bob Bruggers, Wikniski, and pilot Michael Farkus also broke their backs. A bone fragment became embedded in his spinal column, paralyzing him for life and forcing him to have a clamp implanted to hold the bones in his back together. Farkus died a year later having never awakened from a coma. Crockett and Woods suffered less serious injury. In August 2000, Wisniski fell from his front porch, and had a number of injuries and complications. These included a fractured back, pneumonia, staph infection, collapsed lungs and kidney failure.{{cite web |quote = He slipped into a coma, coming out of it once when his wife was singing. He sang along until he fell into the coma again. |url = http://slick.org/deathwatch/mailarchive/msg00262.html |title = Celebrity Deathwatch: John Wisniski Sr., Pro Wrestler Johnny Valentine, 72 |accessdate = 2009-03-21 |author = Denny Burkholder |date = 2001-04-24 |work = Celebrity Deathwatch Mailing List |publisher = slick.org |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110110100516/http://slick.org/deathwatch/mailarchive/msg00262.html |archivedate = 2011-01-10 |df = }} Due to his many injuries he slipped into a coma. At one point he came out of it while his wife was singing to him. He began singing himself but fell back into the coma. His wife had purchased medical insurance through a [[health maintenance organization]] (HMO), but the organization was unwilling to pay for Wisniski's extended stay in the hospital. As a result, [[Lou Thesz]]'s wife convinced the [[Cauliflower Alley Club]] to help contribute to Wisniski's medical bills. Those medical bills reached close to a million dollars. Valentine has been recognized for his wrestling career by several sources. Shortly after his death, he was named the 2001 recipient of ''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]'''s [[PWI Stanley Weston Award|Stanley Weston Award]], a recognition given for lifetime achievement in professional wrestling. He has also been inducted into several halls of fame. He was a member of the inaugural class of inductees to the [[Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame]] in 1996.{{cite web|title=Wrestling Observer Hall of Fame|publisher=''Pro Wrestling Illustrated''|url=http://www.pwi-online.com/pages/hallofame.html|accessdate=2009-03-22}} He is also a member of the [[Stampede Wrestling#Hall of Fame|Stampede Wrestling Hall of Fame]]. In 2006, he was inducted into the [[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]],{{cite web|title=Hall of Famers|publisher=Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum|url=http://www.pwhf.org/halloffamers/inductees.asp|accessdate=2009-03-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327155951/http://www.pwhf.org/halloffamers/inductees.asp|archivedate=2009-03-27|df=}} and he joined the [[St. Louis Wrestling Hall of Fame]] the following year.{{cite web|title=Hall of Fame|publisher=St. Louis Wrestling from the Chase|url=http://www.stlwrestlingfromthechase.com/halloffame.htm|accessdate=2009-03-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080514135222/http://www.stlwrestlingfromthechase.com/halloffame.htm|archivedate=2008-05-14|df=}} Valentine died peacefully in [[River Oaks, Texas]] on April 24, 2001. He was 72. His wife Sharon kept his ashes in her bedroom. She died in 2013. ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[50th State Big Time Wrestling]]''' :*[[NWA Hawaii Tag Team Championship]] ([[NWA Hawaii Tag Team Championship#title history|1 time]]) – with Ripper Collins *'''[[All Japan Pro Wrestling]]''' :*[[NWA International Tag Team Championship|NWA International Tag Team Championship ''(Japan version)'']] ([[NWA International Tag Team Championship#Title history|1 time]]) – with [[Killer Karl Krupp]] :*[[NWA United National Championship]] ([[NWA United National Championship#Title history|1 time]]) *'''[[Big Time Wrestling (Detroit)|Big Time Wrestling]]''' :*[[NWA United States Heavyweight Championship (Detroit version)|NWA United States Heavyweight Championship ''(Detroit version)'']] ([[NWA United States Heavyweight Championship (Detroit version)#Title history|3 times]]) *'''[[World Wrestling Entertainment|Capitol Wrestling Corporation/World Wide Wrestling Federation]]''' :*[[WWWF United States Tag Team {{italic title}} {{Use British English|date=March 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = ''Kalnirnay'' (''Sumangal Press'') | logo = [[File:Kalnirnay_almanac_logo.jpg.png|250 px|Kalnirnay logo]] | type = Private company | founder = [[Jayantrao Salgaonkar]]<ref>http://www.kalnirnay.com/kal_user/about.php</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.expressindia.com/ie/daily/19991020/ige20002.html |title=Kalnirnay to launch regional editions |publisher=Expressindia.com |date=20 October 1999 |accessdate=2011-02-04}}</ref> | industry = [[Almanac]] | key_people = [[Jayraj Salgaokar]] | products = [[almanac]] | services = [[Horoscope]], Kundali Matching, career Reports | revenue = {{INRConvert|550|m}} | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | num_employees = 150 | parent = | subsid = | caption =Kalnirnay | foundation = 1st January 1973 | location_city = [[Mumbai]], Maharashtra | location_country = [[India]] | homepage = https://kalnirnay.com }}
'''''Kalnirnay''''' ''([[Marathi language|Marathi]]: timely decision)'' is a calmanac ([[Calendar]] +[[Almanac]]) published in [[India]]. The almanac gives simplified information about the Panchang, auspicious days, festivals, holidays, sunrise and sunset. It has recipes, stories on health and education, monthly Bhavishya and articles on Hindu astrology.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Sumangal|url=http://www.shop.kalnirnay.com/kal_user/home.php?section=about%20us|publisher=Kalnirnay official website|accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref>
== History == ''Kalnirnay
'' was founded in 1973 by [[Jayantrao Salgaonkar]]. It initially started as a hand-printed almanac for Marathi subscribers. The first issue was sold to 10,000 subscribers. It gradually grew to become the largest selling<ref>{{cite news|last=Kanade|first=Siddhesh|title=Jayantrao Salgaonkar, founder of ''Kalnirnay'' passes away|url=http://www.printweek.in/News/354262,jayantrao-salgaonkar-founder-of-kalnirnay-passes-away.aspx|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=Printweek|date=21 August 2013}}</ref> publication in the world, with around 19 million copies being sold annually.
Its website was launched in 1996, its desktop e-version (e-kalnirnay) was subsequently launched, and it is now available as an [[Android platform|android]] and [[iOS]] application.
== Publication and contents ==
''Kalnirnay'' is published annually, by Sumangal Publishing, as a calendar almanac for all Indian religions.<ref>{{cite news|last=jaisinghani|first=Bella|title=Man who revolutionized the almanac passes away at 84|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Man-who-revolutionized-the-almanac-passes-away-at-84/articleshow/21970061.cms|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=The Times Of India|date=22 August 2013}}</ref> It contains auspicious dates, festivals and celebrations of [[Hindus]], [[Muslims]], [[Christians]], [[Sikhs]], [[Jain religion|Jains]], [[Buddhist|Buddhists]], [[Parsis]] and [[Jews]] in detail. It also provides useful information about Daily [[Panchanga]], auspicious times for weddings ([[Muhurat]]), Daily Sun Rise – Moon Rise Timings,[[Sankashti Chaturthi]] Chandroday (Moon rise) Timing, Monthly Astrological Predictions for all [[Zodiac]] Signs, etc. It is published in nine languages - [[English language|English]], [[Marathi language|Marathi]], [[Hindi]], [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]], [[Tamil language|Tamil]], [[Telugu language|Telugu]] , [[Kannada]], [[Malayalam language|Malayalam]] and [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] with Marathi accounting for the bulk of its readers.<ref>{{cite news|last=Indo Asian|first=News Service|title=Astrologer Jayantrao Salgaonkar dead at 84|url=http://www.newsreporter.in/kalnirnay-almanac-founder-dead-444558|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=News Reporter|date=20 August 2013}}</ref> In addition to dates and times of religious and cultural relevance, each issue also contains articles on topics such as health, food and beauty.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kalnirnay’ almanac founder, Jayantrao Salgaonkar dead|url=http://bombayinformer.com/52801/kalnirnay-almanac-founder-jayantrao-salgaonkar-dead/|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=Bombay Informer|date=20 August 2013}}</ref>
== Products == * Kalnirnay Language Editions : almanac available in 9 languages * Kalnirnay Special Editions : Swadishtha & Aarogya * Kalnirnay Other Editions : Office, Car & Desk Editions * Panchang * Books
== Services == * Muhurat * Compatibility Reports * Janam Patrika * Kundali Matching * Know your gem
==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Companies based in Mumbai]] [[Category:Almanacs]] [[Category:Publishing companies established in 1973]] [[Category:Indian brands]] [[Category:Economy of Maharashtra]] [[Category:1973 establishments in India]]

page.title: List of United States Marine Corps acronyms and expressions

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=October 2013}} <!-- NOTE TO EDITORS: Items on this list must be notable, and [[Wikipedia:Wikipedia is not for things made up one day|not terms that you made up]] or are known to only a small group. --> This is a '''list of [[Acronym and initialism|acronym]]s, expressions''', [[euphemism]]s, [[jargon]], [[military slang]], and sayings in ''common'' or ''formerly common use'' in the [[United States Marine Corps]]. Many of the words or phrases have varying levels of acceptance among different units or communities, and some also have varying levels of [[:Wikt:appropriate|appropriateness]] (usually dependent on how senior the user is in rank). Many terms also have equivalents among other service branches that are not acceptable among Marines, but are comparable in meaning. Many acronyms and terms have come into common use from [[voice procedure]] use over communication channels, translated into the [[ICAO spelling alphabet|phonetic alphabet]], or both. Many are or derive from [[Glossary of nautical terms|nautical terms]] and other [[List of U.S. Navy acronyms|naval terminology]]. Most [[List of vehicles of the United States Marine Corps|vehicles and aircraft]] have a formal acronym or an informal nickname; those are detailed in their own articles.
The scope of this list is to include words and phrases that are unique to or predominantly used by the Marine Corps or the United States Naval Service. Recent joint operations have allowed terms from other military services to leak into the USMC lexicon, but can be found with their originating service's slang list, see [[#See also|the "See also" section]].
{{Horizontal TOC|nonum=y|limit=2}}
==0–9==
[[File:US Marines Talisman Saber 07.jpg|thumb|150px|Marine wearing 782 gear]]
* '''1st Civ Div''' – 1st Civilian Division. Civilian life, usually applied to Marines facing discharge or retirement. As in "getting assigned to 1st Civ Div." Also occasionally referred to as "1st Couch Company." * '''360''' – Forming a complete circle (as in on a compass (360°)); to put protection all around. * '''48''', '''72''', '''96''' – In hours, the standard [[#L|liberty]] periods of two, three, four days. * '''4th Battalion''' – Pejorative used to describe an individual or unit lacking toughness as in "He was trained in 4th Battalion". Derived from the 4th Battalion of the Recruit Training Regiment at [[MCRD Parris Island]], which trains female enlisted Marines. * '''4th Marine Dimension''' – Derogatory term for the [[4th Marine Division]], the division to which the ground combat element of the [[Marine Forces Reserve]] is assigned; used by active duty Marines to denote displeasure with the difference in culture and operating procedures within the division as opposed to active duty units. * '''5.56 hickey''' – A scar or blister resulting from a burn suffered (usually on the neck) due to hot [[#B|brass]]. * '''7 Day Store/Troop Store/Mini P''' – Convenience store (Mini-P denotes a "mini" or smaller sized version of the PX, or Post-Exchange). * '''Deuce Gear''' – Standard issue web gear, combat gear, or field equipment, such as [[All-purpose Lightweight Individual Carrying Equipment|ALICE]], [[MOLLE (military)|MOLLE]], or [[Improved Load Bearing Equipment|ILBE]]. Named after standard Marine Corps Form 782, which Marines formerly signed when they took custody of and responsibility for their equipment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/782-gear|title=Marine Corps Dictionary: 782 Gear|last=Knight|first=Glenn B.|publisher=[[Answers.com]]|accessdate=2008-10-19}}</ref> * '''8 [[Ship's bell|bells]]''' – Signal for the end of a four-hour watch, so named for the increase in bell strike each half-hour of the watch.<ref name="NMM">{{cite web|url=http://www.nmm.ac.uk/collections/nelson/viewObject.cfm?ID=EQA0482|title=Ship's Bell|publisher=[[National Maritime Museum]]|accessdate=2008-04-07}}</ref> * '''8th & I''' – Nickname for [[Marine Barracks, Washington, D.C.]] so named from its street address at the corner of [[Streets and highways of Washington, D.C.|8th and I Streets SE]].
==A==
* '''Aboard''' – Term for all personnel being accounted for in a building, such as a classroom. * '''Above my/your [[pay grade]]''' – Expression denying responsibility or authority (indicating that the issue should be brought to higher-ranking officials); alternatively, a semi-sarcastic way of telling someone that they're not authorized to receive certain information.<ref>[http://blogs.dailymail.com/donsurber/2008/08/17/above-my-pay-grade/ above my pay grade] by Don Surber {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080910212422/http://blogs.dailymail.com/donsurber/2008/08/17/above-my-pay-grade/ |date=September 10, 2008 }}</ref> * '''Acquire(d)''' – euphemism denoting [[theft]].
[[File:Alice01a.jpg|thumb|150px|[[All-purpose Lightweight Individual Carrying Equipment|ALICE]] equipment]]
*'''Air Crew''' – Personnel that work on board any aircraft that can carry a crew (i.e. UH-1, CH-46, CH-53, V-22, etc.), and are normally charged with loading gear, passengers, and manning the door/ tail guns. *'''Air Force pockets''' or '''Army gloves''' – An individual's hands being inside his or her pockets.
<!-- ALICE image above --> * '''ALICE''' – [[All-purpose Lightweight Individual Carrying Equipment]], an older form of combat gear still in occasional use in some Marine activities, replaced by [[MOLLE (military)|MOLLE]] and [[Improved Load Bearing Equipment|ILBE]]<ref>Metzger, E.: ''History Of The Development Of The LINCLOE Load-Carrying Equipment'', July 1975</ref>
* '''All Hands''' – entire ship's company or unit personnel, including all officers and enlisted personnel; also, the [[All Hands|official Navy magazine]] * '''Alphas''' or '''Class As''' – [[Uniforms of the United States Marine Corps#Service uniform|Service Alpha uniform]] from the [[ICAO spelling alphabet|phonetic]] letter [[A]] * '''AMTRAC''' – [[Portmanteau]] for [[Landing Vehicle Tracked|amphibious tractor]]; not to be confused with [[Amtrak|the railroad company Amtrak]]. Also referred to as "Tracks." * '''ANGLICO''' – [[Air Naval Gunfire Liaison Company]] * '''Ant Farm''' – Area of an encampment where the [[Antenna (radio)|radio antennae]] are emplaced. *'''AO''' -- Area of Operation during a deployment. * '''ARMY''' – Ain't Ready to be a Marine Yet – [[backronym]] used for the Army. * '''ASP''' – [[Ammunition]] Supply Point, where ammo is stored and issued. * '''ASVAB waiver''' – Insinuates someone's inability to pass the [[Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery]] (ASVAB) * '''As You Were''' – Order to disregard the immediately preceding order<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/as-you-were as you were] on [[answers.com]]</ref><ref>[http://www.phrases.org.uk/bulletin_board/34/messages/780.html "As you were", "As we were"] on phrases.org.uk</ref> * '''Asiatic''' – [[World War II]] term for eccentric behavior characteristic of men serving too long in the Far East<ref>[[Eugene Sledge|Sledge, E. B.]] ''[[With the Old Breed]]'', 1981 (New York: [[Ballantine Books]], 2007), p. 37.</ref> * '''Aviation Units''' – See also [[List of active United States Marine Corps aircraft squadrons|active squadrons]], [[List of inactive United States Marine Corps aircraft squadrons|inactive squadrons]], & [[List of United States Marine Corps aviation support units|aviation support units]] **HAMS – Headquarters and Maintenance Squadron, also H&MS **HMA – Marine Attack Helicopter Squadron **HMH – Marine Heavy Helicopter Squadron **HMHT – Marine Heavy Helicopter Training Squadron **HML – Marine Light Helicopter Squadrons **HMLA – Marine Light Attack Helicopter Squadron **HMLAT – Marine Light Attack Helicopter Training Squadron **HMM – Marine Medium Helicopter Squadron (formerly HMR) **HMMT – Marine Medium Helicopter Training Squadron **HMR – Marine Helicopter Transport Squadron **HMT – Marine Helicopter Training Squadron (General designation prior to specific communities (i.e. HMHT(CH-53), HMLAT(H-1)) **HMX-1 – Marine Helicopter Squadron One (divided into operational test & Executive transport support) **LAAD Bn – Low-altitude Air Defense Battalion **MABS – Marine Air Base Squadron **MACG – Marine Air Command Group **MACS – Marine Air Control Squadron **MAMS – Marine Aircraft Maintenance Squadron **MASS – Marine Air Support Squadron **MALS – Marine Aviation Logistics Squadron **MATCS – Marine Air Traffic Control Squadron **MCAS – Marine Corps Air Station **MOTS – Marine Operational Training Squadrons **MTACS – Marine Tactical Air Command Squadron **MWSS – Marine Wing Support Squadron **MWCS – Marine Wing Communications Squadron **MWHS – Marine Wing Headquarters squadron **MWSG – Marine Wing Support Group **SOES – Station Operations and Engineer Squadron **VMAQ – Marine Tactical Electronic Warfare Squadron **VMA – Marine Attack Squadron **VMAT – Marine Attack Training Squadron **VMB – Marine Bombing Squadron **VMC – Marine Composite Squadron **VMCJ – Marine Composite Reconnaissance Squadron **VMD – Marine Photographic Squadron **VMF – Marine Fighter Squadron **VMF(N) – Marine Night Fighter Squadron **VMFA – Marine Fighter Attack Squadron **VMFA(AW) – Marine All-Weather Fighter Attack Squadron **VMFAT – Marine Fighter Attack Training Squadron **VMFP – Marine Tactical Reconnaissance Squadron **VMGR – Marine Aerial Refueler/Transport Squadron **VMGRT – Marine Aerial Refueler/Transport Training Squadron **VMJ – Marine Reconnaissance Squadron / Marine Target Towing Detachments **VML – Marine Glider Squadron **VMM – Marine Medium Tiltrotor Squadron (formerly HMM, HMH & VMFA) **VMMT – Marine Medium Tiltrotor Training Squadron (formerly HMMT) **VMO – Marine Observation Squadron **VMP – Marine Patrol Squadron **VMR – Marine Transport Squadron **VMS – Marine Scouting Squadron **VMSB – Marine Scout Bombing Squadron **VMTB – Marine Torpedo Bombing Squadron **VMTD – Marine Target Towing Detachment **VMU – Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Squadron **VMX – Marine Tiltrotor Operational Test and Evaluation Squadron **WES – Wing Engineer Squadron **WTS – Wing Transport Squadron **ZMQ – Marine Barrage Balloon Squadrons * '''[[wikt:aye aye, sir|Aye-Aye]]''' – Nautical term used as a response to orders meaning "I understand the orders I have received and will carry them out"; ''aye'' (descended from Middle English ''yai'') dialectical for 'yes',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?search=aye&searchmode=none |title=Online Etymology Dictionary |publisher=Etymonline.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-07}}</ref> once common in the regions from which the Royal Navy drew its sailors
==B== [[File:Bag nasty.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[A-ration|bag nasty]], breakfast version]]
* '''Back on the Block''' – Behaving like a civilian. * '''Bag Nasty''' a.k.a. "Box Nasty" – [[A-ration]] brown-bag meal issued to Marines (usually recruits or those in-field): it often contains a sandwich, a boiled egg, fruit, potato chips, juice or milk.<ref>[http://www.doubletongued.org/index.php/dictionary/bag_nasty/ bag nasty] on [[Double-Tongued Dictionary]]</ref><!-- bag nasty image above --> * '''BAH''' (a.k.a. "bee ay aych" – [[Basic Allowance for Housing]]: Supplemental pay for living off-base; previously known as Basic Allowance for Quarters (BAQ). * '''BAMCIS''' – a [[mnemonic]] For military tacticians: Begin the planning, Arrange [[reconnaissance]], Make reconnaissance, Complete the planning, Issue orders, Supervise.<ref>[http://acronyms.thefreedictionary.com/BAMCIS BAMCIS] on [[TheFreeDictionary.com]]</ref> It is also used as an exclamation of success or accomplishment. * '''[[Barney & Friends|Barney]]-style''' – to perform strictly according to regulation; [[idiot proof]]; simplified for the benefit of mental underachievers; often said as "'''Breaking it down Barney-style'''" or "Mr. Potato Head style"; Bert and Ernie for the 1980s and 1990s Marines<ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/by%20the%20numbers by the numbers] on [[Merriam-Webster]] OnLine</ref> * '''[[Barracks]]''' – On base housing for Marines who have no dependents, any dependents living with them. Military dormitory rooms. * '''Barracks Cover''' – Fabric-cover [[peaked cap|frame cap]] worn green with the [[Uniforms of the United States Marine Corps#Service uniform|service uniform]] and white with the [[Uniforms of the United States Marine Corps#Dress uniform|dress uniform]]; traditionally officers wear this cap with [[quatrefoil]] and gilt devices that increase with rank. * '''Barracks Rat''' – Guy who stays in the barracks instead of going into town.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Forum|title=Military Jargon, Lingo, & Slang {{!}} Share Your Military Jargon Today|url=https://www.vetfriends.com/lingo/index.cfm?sort=abc&view=all|website=www.vetfriends.com|accessdate=11 July 2016}}</ref> * '''Barracks Bunny''' – Common term for Female Marines that tend or are rumored to sleep around in the barracks, also referred to as "hopping from room to room". * '''BAS''' – Battalion Aid Station: A unit's medical post for routine ailments and injuries; also [[United States Military Pay|Basic Allowance for Subsistence]]. See also [[#S|sick bay]]. * '''Battery Operated Grunt''' – combat radio operator. * '''Battle Blaze''' – original name for the [[1st Marine Division (United States)|1st]] & [[2nd Marine Division (United States)|2nd Marine Division]] [[shoulder sleeve insignia]]s commemorating service in the [[Guadalcanal Campaign|Battle of Guadalcanal]]. * '''Battle Pin''' – [[Tie clip|Tie clasp]] or tie tack; until the start of [[World War II]] a metal bar worn on shirt collar. * '''Battle Sight Zero''' or '''BZO''' – [[calibration|calibrated]] settings on a gun[[Sight (device)|sight]] that contribute to accuracy; used as default before adjusting [[windage]] or [[elevation (ballistics)|elevation]]; also used as verb when triangulating a BZO. [[File:Military Birth Control Glasses.jpg|thumb|150px|[[GI glasses|BCG]]s]] * '''BB Counter''' – Marine whose duties are the handling, storage, issue of [[Ammunition|ordnance]].<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/bb-stacker BB stacker] on [[Answers.com]]</ref><!-- BCGs image above --> * '''BCGs''' or '''BCs''' – [[GI glasses|Birth Control Glasses]] or Boot Camp Glasses: military issue glasses worn at [[recruit training]]; so called because they make the wearer too ugly to engage in [[Human sexual behavior|sexual relations]]. See also [[#P|portholes]] & [[#R|RPGs]]. * '''Beans, Bullets, and Band-Aids''' – Meant to imply the basic supplies that military logisticians must provide for: [[ration]]s, [[ammunition]], medical care. * '''[[Beer garden|Beer Garden]]''' – Social area permitting the consumption of alcohol etc.; may contain [[barbecue]] or [[picnic]] facilities. * '''Belay''' – To cancel an order; to stop; to [[Belaying|firmly secure a line]]. * '''Below Decks''' – Area below the surface (deck) of a ship. * '''BEQ''' – Bachelor Enlisted Quarters: living spaces for single enlisted Marines; usually a [[barracks]].<ref>[http://acronyms.thefreedictionary.com/BEQ BEQ] on [[TheFreeDictionary.com]]</ref> * '''BCD''' – [[Bad Conduct Discharge]]; also known as Big Chicken Dinner. * '''Big Green Weenie''' – Denotes that a Marine has been "screwed over" or cheated by the Marine Corps.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Knight|first1=Glenn B.|title=Unofficial, Unabridged Dictionary For Marines – An attempt to capture the lexicon of the United States Marine Corps|url=http://4mermarine.com/USMC/dictionary/g.html|website=4mermarine.com|accessdate=11 July 2016}}</ref> * '''Bird, Ball & Fish Hook''' – derogatory term used to describe the Eagle Globe and Anchor of the beloved Marine Corps Emblem. * '''[[Bitt|Binnacle List]]''' – sick list: those excused from duty for health reasons; traditionally posted on or near the [[binnacle]]. * '''[[Hazing|Blanket Party]]''' – Group assault: victim's head is covered by a blanket so the perpetrators can't be identified. * '''[[Blood stripe]]''' – Red band on dress uniform trousers; traditionally said to symbolize blood shed by Marine officers and [[non-commissioned officer|NCO]]s during the [[Battle of Chapultepec]]; worn by [[non-commissioned officer|NCO]]s and officers. * '''Blooper''' – [[Grenade launcher]]: from the distinctive noise made when one is fired. See also [[#T|thump gun]]. * '''Blousing Garters''' – The correct name for "boot bands." * '''BLT''' – Battalion Landing Team: the [[ground combat element]] of a [[Marine Expeditionary Unit|MEU]]; not to be confused with a [[BLT sandwich|Bacon, Lettuce, and Tomato sandwich]]. * '''Blue Falcon''' – A '''buddy-fucker''' (see below). * '''Blues''' or '''Dress Blues''' – [[Uniforms of the United States Marine Corps#Dress uniform|Blue Dress uniform]]. * '''BLUF''' – Bottom Line Up Front. * '''Bn''' – [[battalion]]. * '''[[Boondoggle (project)|boondoggle]]''' – project or trip on government time or expense that serves no purpose other than to entertain the person making it. * '''Boot''' – A term for Marines who are new to the Marine Corps. Derived from the term "boot camp", to insinuate that the Marine is fresh out of boot camp. Generally used as a pejorative term (even if in an affectionate manner) in the Fleet and elsewhere, sometimes as a way to explain that new Marines should know their place. It can also be used as a term for a Marine who is new to a rank or billet. e.g. – "He's a boot Corporal". Meaning, said Marine was just recently promoted to Corporal. Also used by infantry Marines as a pejorative for any other Marine who has not gone on a combat deployment, regardless of rank or time in service. [[File:Yellow Footprints.jpg|thumb|150px|The first thing a recruit sees at [[United States Marine Corps Boot Camp|boot camp]]]] * '''Boot Bands''' – Elastic bands or metal springs rolled into the hem of the trousers to blouse them near the top of the boot. * '''Boots and Utes''' – The [[Marine Corps Combat Utility Uniform|utility uniform]] without the normal uniform blouse, typically used for PT.<!-- boot camp image above --> * '''[[United States Marine Corps Recruit Training|boot camp]]''' – Training hub for new Marines at [[Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island|Parris Island]], [[South Carolina|SC]] and [[Marine Corps Recruit Depot San Diego|San Diego]], [[California|CA]]. * '''BOQ''' – Bachelor Officer Quarters: housing for single Marine officers.<ref>[http://www.yourdictionary.com/boq BOQ] on YourDictionary.com</ref><ref>[http://acronyms.thefreedictionary.com/BOQ BOQ] on [[TheFreeDictionary.com]]</ref> * '''Box-kicker''' – Pejorative for a Marine who works in supply (either the [[List of United States Marine Corps MOS|MOS]] 3043 (Supply Administration) or usually a 3051 – (Basic Warehouseman)). [[warehouse]] clerk.<ref name="Box Kicker">{{cite web|url=http://www.dcvelocity.com/articles/?article_id=2002&channel=157&source=relatedContent|title=Snake Eater to Box Kicker|last=Geary|first=Steve| date=August 2008|work=DC VELOCITY|publisher=Agile Business Media, LLC|accessdate=2008-11-11|archiveurl=http://bus.utk.edu/cba/news_articles/DCV_Schwartz_profile.pdf|archivedate=August 2008}}</ref> *brove * '''Brain Bucket''' – [[Helmet]].<ref name="vetfriends.com">{{cite web|title=Military Jargon, Lingo, & Slang {{!}} Share Your Military Jargon Today|url=https://www.vetfriends.com/lingo/index.cfm?sort=abc&view=all|website=www.vetfriends.com|accessdate=11 July 2016}}</ref> * '''Brain-housing Group''' – Pejorative for a Marine's head or skull.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/brain-housing-group brain housing group] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> * '''Brain Strap''' – Elastic strap used for securing eyeglasses during rigorous activities; often found on BCG's. * '''[[Brass]]''' – 1) Shell casings; 2) Uniform insignia; 3) Senior officers (cf. rank insignia); 4) (BRASS) USMC shooting technique: Breathe, Relax, Aim, Slack, Squeeze. * '''[[Military brat (U.S. subculture)|brat]]''' – A servicemember's child. * '''Break-off Session''' – Extraordinarily strenuous or tiring physical activity; usually [[#P|PT]]. * '''[[Military prison|Brig]]''' – Military [[prison]] on ship or ashore. * '''Brig Rat''' – Marine who has served much brig time; also used to refer to the 5831 MOS Marines who serve as corrections specialists (guards).<ref>[http://www.jargondatabase.com/Jargon.aspx?id=852 brig rat] on Jargon Database.com</ref> * '''Brightwork''' – Shiny metal that Marines must polish.<ref>[http://www.yourdictionary.com/brightwork brightwork] on YourDictionary.com</ref> * '''Broke-dick''' – Any person who does not perform up to standards, or a sorry piece of equipment.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Forum|title=Military Jargon, Lingo, & Slang {{!}} Share Your Military Jargon Today|url=https://www.vetfriends.com/lingo/index.cfm?sort=abc&view=all|website=www.vetfriends.com|accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> * '''Broke''' – Feeling severe fatigue. Also refers to anything that isn't working. * '''[[Packed lunch|Brown-bagger]]''' – Marines (usually married) who live off base; instead of eating at mess halls they pack meals to work.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/brown-bag brown bag] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> * '''Buddy-fucker (Blue Falcon)''' – One who disregards a team-member's welfare; a Marine who will turn on a fellow Marine in order to save himself/herself.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Knight|first1=Glenn B.|title=Unofficial, Unabridged Dictionary For Marines – An attempt to capturethe lexicon of the United States Marine Corps|url=http://4mermarine.com/USMC/dictionary/b.html|website=4mermarine.com|accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> * '''Bug Juice''' – [[Insect repellent]]. * '''[[Bulkhead (partition)|Bulkhead]]''' – A wall.<ref name="Jarheadbook" /> * '''Bum Scoop''' – Bad information.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/bum-scoop bum scoop] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> * '''Burning Man''' – A Marine who is scorched by hot gun casings. * '''Bus Driver''' – Air Force pilot; so called because early USAF uniforms were said to resemble those of municipal streetcar officials. * '''[[wikt:bust#Etymology_2|Busted]]''' – Reduced in rank. * '''Butt Pack''' – Small pack fastened to the waist in the back. Usually the field issued first aid kit. See also [[Fanny pack]].<ref>[http://www.thefreedictionary.com/butt+pack butt pack] on [[TheFreeDictionary.com]]</ref> * '''Butter Bar''' – A second lieutenant, due to the gold color of his rank insignia. * '''"By your leave sir'''/'''ma'am."''' – Used with a salute prior to passing senior officers who might be advancing in the same direction; protocol states the senior must acknowledge by returning salute with phrase "Carry on" before the junior passes on the left.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/by-your-leave by your leave] on [[Answers.com]]</ref>
==C==
* '''C & S''' – "Clean & Sober" notation formerly entered on the liberty list beside the names of Marines returning from liberty in that condition. * '''CACO''' – Casualty Assistance Calls/Counseling Officer, a Marine detailed to help the family of a Marine killed, wounded, or captured in the line of duty.<ref>[https://www.manpower.usmc.mil/portal/page?_pageid=278,1952478&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL Casualty Assistance Calls Officer]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} on usmc.mil</ref><ref>[http://acronyms.thefreedictionary.com/Caco CACO] on [[TheFreeDictionary.com]]</ref> * '''Cadillacs''' – boots; method of transportation when no other vehicle is available. Also refers to all leather combat boots. * '''Call Out''' – To challenge, often by announcing incriminating information about a person. See also [[wikt:drop a dime|drop a dime]]. * '''Cammies''' – [[Marine Corps Combat Utility Uniform|camouflage utility uniform]].<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/cammies cammie] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> * '''Camp Living Room''' – Duty station after discharge. Civilian life. 1980s usage. * '''Campaign Cover''' – Official term for the green [[campaign hat]] worn by [[drill instructor]]s and designated rifle range personnel. Occasionally referred to as a "[[Smokey Bear]]" for obvious reasons. See also [[#F|field hat]], [[#H|hat]], & [[#S|smokey bear/brown]]. * '''Cannon Cocker''' – [[artillery]]man.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/cannon-cocker cannon cocker] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> See also [[#G|gun bunny]] and [[#R|red leg]]. * '''Cannon Fodder''' – Marines regarded merely as material to be expended in war. * '''Canoe U.''' – nickname for [[United States Naval Academy]] at [[Annapolis, Maryland|Annapolis]], [[Maryland]].<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/canoe-u Canoe U] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> See also [[#S|South Maryland Small Boat & Barge Institute]]. * '''CAR''' – Short for Combat Action Ribbon * '''[[Mast (naval)|Captain's Mast]]''' – [[#O|Office Hours]] afloat. The term "Captain's Mast" is almost universally negative, implying [[Nonjudicial punishment|non-judicial punishment]]. The modern Navy and Marine Corps use the term "Meritorious Mast" to announce any ceremony involving the meritorious award of a higher rank or of a particular recognition or honor. USA & USAF refer to this as "Article 15" hearing.<ref>[http://www.thefreedictionary.com/captain's+mast captain's mast] on [[TheFreeDictionary.com]]</ref> * '''Carry On''' – Order to continue after being interrupted. Also music played immediately following playing of "colors" to inform people to resume activities. * '''CAS''' – [[Close air support|Close Air Support]], aircraft fire on ground troops in support of nearby friendly troops. * '''CASEVAC''' – [[Casualty evacuation|CASualty EVACuation]], emergency evacuation of injured personnel from combat zone by any modes transport available to nearest triage area, treatment area, or field hospital. As opposed to a [[Medical evacuation|MEDEVAC]] which is the transport from a field hospital to a Medical Treatment Facility.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/casevac-2 CASEVAC] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> See also [[#M|MEDEVAC]]. * '''Casual Company''' – A holding unit/formation of Marines awaiting one of the following: discharge from the Corps, training (usually at a formal school), or deployment to a unit.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/casual-company-or-platoon casual company or platoon] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> * '''CAX''' – [[Combined Arms]] eXercise. Outdated term, it has since been replaced by the ITX (Integrated Training eXercise).<ref>[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/ops/cax.htm CAX] on GlobalSecurity.org</ref> * '''CBRN''' – [[Chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear|Chemical, Biological, Radiological, and Nuclear]]. See also [[#N|NBC]]. * '''CCU''' – [[corrections|Correctional]] Custody Unit, a hard-labor and heavy discipline unit overseen by [[#M|MP]]s or Navy [[Master-at-arms#United States Navy|Masters-at-Arms]] to which Marines and Sailors found guilty of minor [[#U|UCMJ]] offenses through [[#N|NJP]] are sent for up to 30 days in lieu of confinement in the [[#B|brig]].<ref>[http://acronyms.thefreedictionary.com/Correctional+Custody+Unit CCU] on [[TheFreeDictionary.com]]</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.marines.mil/units/mciwest/mcasmiramar/Pages/2000/Corectional%20Custody%20Unit%20begins%20Day%20One.aspx| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816111002/http://www.marines.mil/units/mciwest/mcasmiramar/Pages/2000/Corectional%20Custody%20Unit%20begins%20Day%20One.aspx| dead-url=yes| archive-date=2016-08-16|title=Correctional Custody Unit begins Day One|date=2000-10-13|work=[[Marine Corps Air Station Miramar]] public affairs|publisher=[[United States Marine Corps]]|accessdate=2008-11-29}} </ref>
