* '''Chairborne''' or '''Chairborne Ranger''' – Someone who works in an office environment, a play on [[Airborne forces|airborne]].<ref>[http://encarta.msn.com/dictionary_1861596101/chairborne.html chairborne] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421094404/http://encarta.msn.com/dictionary_1861596101/chairborne.html |date=2008-04-21 }} on [[Encarta]]. [https://web.archive.org/web/20150212223019/http://www.webcitation.org/5kwt45oK2Archived] 2009-10-31.</ref>
[[File:USMC-E2.svg|thumb|150px|A single [[Chevron (insignia)#Rank insignia|chevron]]]]
* '''Charlies''' or '''Chucks''' – The [[Uniforms of the United States Marine Corps#Service uniform|service "C" uniform]], consisting of the short-sleeve khaki shirt and green trousers. * '''Chaser''' – Pejorative for a Marine assigned prisoner escort duties, an escort for a single prisoner or detail of prisoners.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/brig-chaser brig chaser] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> * '''Check Fire''' – Order to stop firing due to a safety condition, possible error or mistarget. * '''Chest Candy''' – Used in reference to the ribbons and medals on a Marine's uniform.
<!-- Chevron image above --> *'''[[Chevron (insignia)#Rank insignia|chevron]]''' – Symbols of enlisted ranks above private, usually not acceptably called "stripes" unless describing the [[United States Marine Corps rank insignia|rank insignia]] itself. *'''[[China Marines]]''' – Those United States Marines from the [[4th Marine Regiment (United States)|4th Marine Regiment]] who were stationed in [[Shanghai]], [[China]] during 1927–1941 * '''Chinese Field Day''' – A form of [[#F|field day]] where every item from a room is removed for cleaning; when tending to last much longer than necessary, it is used as a punishment, typically for unsatisfactory performance in routine field day.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} * '''Chit''' – [[Voucher]], receipt, letter, or note, entitling the bearer to special treatment, such as medical restrictions from duty; derived from [[Hindi]] word for "letter", "''chitti''".<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Chit chit] on [[Reference.com]]</ref> * '''CIF''' – Consolidated Issue Facility, a place on a station where all personal equipment is stored and issued, often contracted to civilians.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmccif.com/ |title=CIF online |publisher=Usmccif.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303184508/http://www.usmccif.com/ |archivedate=2012-03-03 |df= }}</ref> * '''CID''' – Criminal Investigation Division, is an accredited Federal law enforcement agency of the U.S. Marine Corps whose mission it is to conduct official criminal investigations into misdemeanor and felony offenses committed on Marine Corps installations as may directed and not under the primary jurisdiction of the [[Naval Criminal Investigative Service]] (NCIS). These Marines are not formal law enforcement officers per se, and only perform investigations under the cognizance of NCIS. * '''Civvies''' – Civilian clothing or [[Mufti (dress)|mufti]].<ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/civvies civvies] on [[Merriam-Webster]] online</ref><ref>[http://www.thefreedictionary.com/civvies civvies] on [[TheFreeDictionary.com]]</ref><ref> [http://www.yourdictionary.com/civvies civvies] on YourDictionary.com</ref> * '''CLP''' – [[MIL-L-63460|Cleaner, Lubricant, Preservative]], teflon-based cleaning and lubricating fluid used for maintaining small arms. Also slang for [[coffee]]. * '''[[wikt:clusterfuck|Cluster fuck]]''' – Chaotic and messy situation from multiple mistakes or problems happening in rapid succession. See also [[#G|goat rope / goat rodeo / goat screw]]. * '''CMC''' – Acronym for [[Commandant of the Marine Corps]].<ref>[http://acronyms.thefreedictionary.com/Commandant+of+the+Marine+Corps CMC] on [[TheFreeDictionary.com]]</ref> * '''COB''' – [[End of Day|Close Of Business]], the end of working hours; or Close Order Battle, a synonym for CQB. * '''COC''' – [[Combat Operations Center]], the command post for a [[combat arms]] unit, usually of battalion-size or larger; personnel assigned to the COC may derisively refer to such duty as "coc-watch" or "working the coc". * '''COG''' – [[Corporal Of the Guard]], The acting corporal, (or near rank) that acts under the SOG [[Sgt. of the Guard]] on watch, radio watch, or post. * '''Colonel''' – Proper means of addressing [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonels]] and [[Colonel (United States)|colonels]]. * '''Commie Killer''' – Derogative term used for the hand which a Marine masturbates with, originates from the fact that most men masturbate with their dominant hand, i.e. their firing hand. * '''CONUS''' – [[Contiguous United States|CONtinental United States]] (48 states excluding [[Alaska]] and [[Hawaii]]), as opposed to [[#O|OCONUS]]. * '''Corfams''' – Uniform [[dress shoe]]s made from [[Artificial leather|poromeric imitation leather]]. * '''Corpsman''' – [[United States Navy Hospital Corpsman|Navy hospital corpsman]] attached to a Marine unit; also known as "[[#D|doc]]"; inappropriate to address as "[[Combat medic|medic]]" or "aid man".<ref>[http://usmilitary.about.com/od/enlistedjob1/a/hm.htm corpsman] on [[About.com]]</ref> See also [[#B|boxsee]]. * '''Cover''' – Headgear (a hat) [[Cover (military)|protection from enemy fire]]. * '''Cover and Alignment''' – When in a formation, this refers to the proper distance between those next to, in front of, and behind a person; to seek the proper interval.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090304134924/http://dept.kent.edu/afrotc/Cadets/Downloads/FTP/Drill%20and%20Instruction%20Ditties.doc cover and alignment] on [[Kent State University]] [[ROTC]]</ref> * '''CQB''' or '''CQC''' – [[Close Quarters Battle|Close Quarters Battle/Combat]], combat within a confined space, such as [[urban warfare]]. See also [[#M|MOUT]]. * '''Crew-Served''' – Short for [[Infantry support weapon|crew-served weapon]]; also large and very powerful, based on a crew-served weapon being such. * '''Cruise''' – Deployment aboard ship; or enlistment period, inappropriately called a stint. * '''[[CS gas|CS]]''' – 2-chlorobenzalmalononitrile, a white solid powder commonly used for [[CBRN defense]] training. * '''Cumshaw''' – Something extra or free, given as a favor or gift; [[pidgin]] expression using the [[Chinese language|Chinese]] word for "grateful thanks", "''kamsia''".<ref>[http://www.answers.com/cumshaw cumshaw] on [[Answers.com]]</ref>
==D== * '''D & D''' – Drunk and Disorderly, an entry formerly made on the liberty list beside the name of any Marine returning from liberty in that condition; not to be confused with the game, "Dungeons & Dragons." * '''''Daijoubu''''' – [[Okay|OK]], from [[Japanese language|Japanese]] for "don't worry". * '''Daily 7''' or '''Daily 16''' – [[Static stretching|stretches]] and [[isometric exercise|exercises]] used as a [[Warming up|warmup]] for other, more strenuous [[physical exercise|physical training]]. * '''Dark Green/Light Green''' – Common reference to a Marine's skin color. Marines are not black or white, the saying goes, only different shades of green. * '''Dead Horse''' – To draw advance pay out of the normal pay cycle, the Marine is then obligated to repay the debt at the government's convenience. * '''[[Deck (ship)|deck]]''' – Floor or surface of the earth; to punch or knock down with one blow.<ref name="Jarheadbook"/>
[[File:Teufel Hunden US Marines recruiting poster.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Devil Dog]]]]
* '''[[wikt:deep six|Deep Six]]''' – To dispose of by throwing overboard ship. * '''[[Detachment (military)|Detachment]]''' – A portion of a unit sent independently of its parent organization, usually in support of a larger headquarters; or a small stand alone unit isolated geographically from its parent command. * '''Deuce''' – Reference to the number two in various unit or equipment names; the senior intelligence officer for a unit; * '''Deuce Gear''' – See [[#0–9|782 gear]], from the last digit in that term. * '''[[Devil Dog]]''' or '''Devil''' – Nickname for Marines, from the [[German language|German]] word "''Teufel<!-- please do not edit the spelling or voracity unless consensus at the Devil Dog article changes -->hunden''", supposedly given by German troops at the [[Battle of Belleau Wood]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Memorial Day, Belleau Wood Style|url=http://www.marines.mil/unit/marforeur/Pages/Memorial%20Day,%20Belleau%20Wood%20Style.aspx|first=MSgt Phil|last=Mehringer|accessdate=2011-01-21|publisher=United States Marine Corps}} </ref> though the correct grammatical form would be "''Teufelshunde''".<ref name="Flippo">{{cite web|last=Flippo|first=Hyde|title=German Myth 13: Teufelshunde – Devil Dogs|publisher=[[About.com]]|url=http://german.about.com/od/culture/a/germyth13.htm}}</ref><ref><nowiki>{{cite web|url=</nowiki>http://www.stripes.com/blogs/the-rumor-doctor/the-rumor-doctor-1.104348/did-marines-not-german-soldiers-coin-the-phrase-devil-dogs-1.130602#<nowiki/>|title=Did Marines, not German soldiers, coin the phrase ‘Devil Dogs’?|last=Schogol|first=Jeff|date=January 4, 2011|publisher=[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]]<nowiki>|accessdate=27 January 2011}}</nowiki></ref> * '''Devil Nuts''' – A regional variation of devil dog and nickname for Marines. Popular with Marines serving at Marine Barracks Japan (Late 1990s era). * '''Devil Pup''' – Nickname for a Marine's child(ren); a member of the [[Young Marines]]; a [[wikt:patronize|patronizing]] nickname for a junior Marine. Mostly used by senior Marines to reference junior Marines in a polite way, and commonly used around higher ups. * '''DGAF''' – Doesn't/Don't Give A Fuck. Generally coincides with one who is [[#O|OFP]]. * '''DI''' – [[Drill instructor|Drill Instructor]], inappropriate to use the Army term "drill sergeant". * '''DI Hut''' – Office for drill instructors in a platoon's squad bay; doubles as sleeping quarters for the drill instructor on duty. See also [[#H|house mouse]]. * '''Dickskinner''' or '''Dickbeater''' – Human [[hand]].
[[File:Drill sergeant screams.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Drill instructor|DI]]]]
* '''Diddy Bop''' – Poor performance in [[Military parade|close order drill]], or marching in a manner that does not present a crisp military appearance. One who conducts himself/herself in this manner is labelled a diddy bopper. * '''Diet Recruit''' or '''Diet Tray''' – A recruit in Boot Camp who has been deemed overweight according to regulations. These recruits are usually the last through the chow line and have their meals inspected by DI's. * '''Digis''' or '''Diggis''' – Digital camouflage such as [[MARPAT]]; also refers to the digital-patterned [[Marine Corps Combat Utility Uniform|MCCUU]]. * '''Dime Out''' – To reveal incriminating information about a person. See also [[#C|call out]]. * '''[[Disneyland]] East''' – [[Headquarters Marine Corps]] at [[Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington, Virginia]]. * '''Doc''' or '''Devil Doc''' – [[United States Navy Hospital Corpsman|Navy hospital corpsman]] attached to the Marines; Devil Doc is a term of respect normally reserved for Corpsmen who are [[Fleet Marine Force]] qualified or who have served in combat with Marines. * '''[[Dog and Pony Show]]''' – Any display, demonstration, or appearance by Marines at the request of seniors for the pleasure of someone else, such as a ceremony or parade; also, pejorative for the requirement for over-perfection of such a venue. * '''Doggie''' – Enlisted member of the [[United States Army]], from the diminutive "dog-face". * '''Donkey Dick''' – Specifically, a [[jerrycan]] fuel spout. Alternatively, slang for virtually any piece of equipment having a generally cylindrical or [[Phallus|phallic]] shape with unknown, or obscure official name. For example, a static hook suspended from an overhead helicopter for the purpose of picking up external loads. * '''Dope''' – Data On Previous Engagements, information, or sight settings or wind corrections for a rifle under given conditions. * '''DPICM''' – [[Dual-Purpose Improved Conventional Munition]]s, a specialized artillery round that releases [[cluster bomb|sub-munitions]]. * '''Drill''' – [[Military parade|Close order drill]], the procedures and methodology of handling weapons and [[marching|moving]] troops about in an orderly fashion, used to indoctrinate recruits in obedience to [[Drill commands|commands]] and military appearance.<ref>[http://usmilitary.about.com/od/theorderlyroom/l/bldrill.htm Individual drill] on [[About.com]]</ref><ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/122108/close-order-drill close order drill] on [[Encyclopædia Britannica]]</ref> * '''Drill Hat''' – A [[Drill Instructor]], usually the second most senior behind the [[#SDI|SDI]] and who specializes in the instruction of [[close order drill]]. * '''DRMOed''' – To dispose of an item by taking it to the [[Defense Reutilization and Marketing Service|Defense Reutilization and Marketing Office]] (DRMO). * '''Drug Deal''' – To obtain needed supplies, equipment or services outside official channels via barter rather than theft. * '''[[Dry fire]]''' – Practice firing of a weapon without using ammunition in order to refine body position and other shooting fundamentals. * '''DTG''' – [[Date-time group|Date-Time Group]], a numeric code denoting the time and date of a [[Automated Message Handling System|message]]. * '''Dual-cool''' or '''Double-trouble''' – A Marine that possesses both the [[Parachutist Badge (United States)|parachutist]] and [[Diver insignia|diver]] badges, usually associated with the [[United States Marine Air-Ground Task Force Reconnaissance| Reconnaissance community]].<ref>Melson, Charles D. ''Marine Recon 1940–90'' (Oxford: Osprey Publishing, 1994, reprinted 2003), p. 26.</ref> * '''Dummy Cord''' – [[Lanyard]] or [[tether]] used to secure a piece of equipment to an anchor to prevent losing it. * '''Duty NCO''' or '''Duty''' – Sentry responsible for patrol and security of a specific area (usually a barracks or working space in garrison). See also [[#F|fire watch]] and [[#C|OOD]]
==E==
[[File:Globeanchor.svg|thumb|150px|[[Eagle, Globe, and Anchor|EGA]]]]
* '''EAS''' – End of Active Service, the date of discharge from active duty. * '''EGA''' – [[Eagle, Globe, and Anchor]], the emblem of the Marine Corps. The usage of the term discouraged by older Marines. * '''Eight Ball''' – A Marine who lacks an aggressive spirit.<ref>[[Richard Tregaskis|Tregaskis, Richard]]. ''[[Guadalcanal Diary (book)|Guadalcanal Diary]]'' (Garden City, New York: Blue Ribbon Books, 1943), 16.</ref> * '''Eighth & I''' or '''Eighth & Eye''' – [[Marine Barracks, Washington, D.C.]], located at [[Streets and highways of Washington, D.C.|8th and I Streets SE]]. See also [[#0–9|8th & I]]. * '''Einstein''' – A derogatory term for a Marine who is found to be responsible for a particularly notable unwise action or plan. * '''EM''' – Enlisted Marine/Man, very inappropriate to use today. * '''Elephant Hat''' – [[Pith helmet]] first issued in 1940 and worn by rifle range coaches today. * '''Embed''' – To place within, or fix in place. * '''National Ensign''' – A.k.a. colors, national flag. * '''EOD''' – [[Bomb Disposal|Explosive Ordnance Disposal]], responsible for the safe handling, deactivation, and removal of unexploded ordnance, the military version of a bomb squad. * '''EPD''' – Extra Punitive Duties, punishment assigned where the individual is required to perform cleaning duties after working hours (on his or her [[#L|liberty]] time). * '''EPW''' – Enemy [[prisoner of war|Prisoner of War]]. Eyeballs - Optometrist
==F==
* '''Fallen Angel''' – Marine Officer who failed out of flight school and is now in another MOS. * '''FAP''' – Fleet Assistance Program, a program designed to assign Marines to extra duties outside his or her normal chain of command. Long seen as a means for commands to "reassign" their lowest-performing or misbehaving Marines.
[[File:Refueling Cobra.jpg|thumb|right|150px|AH-1W Cobras at a FARP during Op Iraqi Freedom]]
* '''FARP''' – Forward Area Refueling/Rearming Point or Forward Arming Refueling Point, a space on the battlefield designated for the re-arming and re-fueling of aircraft. * '''Fart Sack''' – [[Cotton mattress cover]]; large sack made of linen that a mattress is inserted into. Serves as a military form of a fitted sheet. * '''FAST''' – Fleet Anti-terrorism Security Team, sarcastically referred to as Fake Ass SEAL Team. * '''Fast-mover''' – Fast-moving [[fixed-wing aircraft]]; term popular during the [[Vietnam War]] but fallen into disuse as [[jet aircraft|jets]] replaced [[propeller]]-powered aircraft. Also used to describe a Marine moving fast (promoted) up the ranks. * '''Fat Barrel''' – Round in the chamber, no magazine inserted. * '''Fat-body''' – Overweight recruit or servicemember. * '''FEBA''' – [[Front line|Forward Edge of the Battle Area]], the [[Line of Departure|line of departure]] where a unit enters enemy territory. * '''Felony Creek''' – Slang for the French Creek area of Camp Lejeune. French Creek is the home for the Marine units that are service and support. Some Marines who reside there think they are back on the block. * '''[[Fiddler's Green]]''' – Imaginary afterlife; paradise. * '''Field 10''' – A physically unattractive female servicemember who becomes an object of desire for male servicemembers after extended time in a field or combat environment away from civilian women. A perfect "10" in the field. * '''[[wikt:field day|Field Day]]''' – Day or portion of day set aside for top-to-bottom cleaning of an area; also as a verb for the act of conducting a field day. * '''Field Expedient''' – [[Improvisation]], to make do with what's available.
[[File:AR-15 field strip.JPG|thumb|150px|field stripped [[M16 rifle|M16]]]]
* '''Field Cover''' – [[Campaign hat|Campaign Cover]], a broad-brimmed felt hat, originally with one straight crease down the middle, then with a Montana peak, worn on expeditionary missions from 1912 to 1942, and then again authorized in 1961 for wear at recruit depots by drill instructors and rifle ranges by marksmanship instructors. See also [[#C|campaign cover]], [[#H|hat]], & [[#S|smokey bear/brown]]. * '''Field Meet''' – Organized sporting competition, often involving athletics or soldierly skills. * '''Field Music''' – Drummer, trumpeter, bugler, fifer; mostly an antiquated term. * '''Field-Strip''' – To disassemble a piece of ordnance or weapon to the major part groups for routine cleaning or lubricating; to strip cigarette butts to their filters before throwing away. Also to remove unwanted items from an MRE in order to save space. * '''Fifty-cal''' – [[M2 Browning machine gun]], from its [[.50 BMG|.50 caliber ammunition]]. See also [[#M|Ma Deuce]]. [[File:Machine gun M2 1.jpg|thumb|150px|[[M2 Browning machine gun|fifty-cal]]]]
* '''[[Defensive fighting position|Fighting Hole]]''' – A defensive position dug into the ground; can be dug for one Marine, a pair, or a weapon crew; formerly known as a "foxhole" by the Army. Marine Corps is "firing hole" "Forward Firing Position" should be considered. * '''Final Duty Station''' – A reference to a Marine's final posting, i.e., [[Heaven]], referencing the last verse of the [[Marine's Hymn]]. * '''Final Protective Fire''' or '''FPF''' – The last volley sent toward an advancing enemy during a Marine unit's withdrawal from defensive position. All weapons are fired simultaneously at maximum rate of fire. * '''[[Fire for effect|Fire for Effect]]''' – Indicates that the adjustment/ranging of [[indirect fire]] is satisfactory and the actual effecting rounds should be fired; also a euphemism for the execution of a plan. * '''Fire Watch''' – Sentry on duty specifically guarding a person, place, object, or area in a non-combat area (such as a barracks); considered under arms but usually unarmed. See also [[#D|duty]] & [[#C|OOD]]. * '''Fire Watch Medal''' – Pejorative for [[National Defense Service Medal]], so named because even recruits rate it despite firewatch being their most important duty. * '''First Lieutenant, Second Award''' – Derogatory term used to describe a former First Lieutenant who has been frocked (promoted ahead of schedule) to Captain. * '''[[First Shirt]]''' – [[Company (military unit)|company]] or [[Artillery battery|battery]] [[First sergeant#United States Marine Corps|First Sergeant]]. * '''Fitness Report''' or '''FITREP''' – Evaluation report written on Marines (sergeant and above) detailing proficiency and conduct and fitness for command, reviewed for promotion. *'''Five-jump Chump''' – A servicemember who has only performed the minimum five [[paratrooper]] jumps to receive the [[Parachutist Badge (United States)#Basic Parachutist Insignia|Basic Parachute Insignia]], as opposed to the [[Parachutist Badge (United States)#Navy & Marine Corps Parachutist Insignia|Navy and Marine Corps Parachutist Insignia]], which requires additional jumps.<ref name="Jarheadbook">{{cite book|last=[[Anthony Swofford|Swofford, Anthony]]|title=Jarhead|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|date=4 March 2003|isbn=0-7432-5428-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xCSTtg6oSPwC&pg=PA164&lpg=PA164&dq=%22five+jump+chump%22&source=bl&ots=y4jApRSfU3&sig=Yr3hmJZvnmS1YzeKS7VEGaf_NXw&hl=en&ei=azv5Scb4LoTK-AbT3MmuAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7#PPA164,M1}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pnwjagatbragg.blogspot.com/2008/07/five-jump-chump-no-more.html |title=five jump chump |publisher=Pnwjagatbragg.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-07}}</ref> * '''[[Flak jacket|Flak Jacket]]''' – Antiquated term for [[ballistic vest]] or body armor. * '''Flak and Kevlar''' – Used when referring to body armor and a helmet respectively (the standard US Military issued helmet is made out of kevlar). * '''Float''' – Deployment aboard ship. * '''Float Widow''' – Unfaithful wife of a Marine or Sailor deployed aboard a ship. a.k.a. '''Med Float Widow'''. * '''FMC''' – Fully Mission Capable, refers to equipment such as aircraft that need no repairs and are fully capable of their intended mission. * '''FMF''' or '''Fleet''' – [[Fleet Marine Force]], the operational forces of the Corps, as opposed to reserve or supporting establishment. * '''FMTU''' – Foreign Military Training Unit. * '''[[FNG syndrome|FNG]]''' – Fucking New Guy, derogatory term for a Marine recently graduated [[recruit training]] and new to a unit. It has far and wide been replaced by the term "boot". *'''Fobbie''' or '''Fobbit''' – A Marine who rarely sees combat; pejorative term for Marines stuck inside a [[forward operating base]]. *'''Follow it''' – Said when a rifle is dropped by a Marine, the Marine is expected to follow it to the ground by doing a push up as punishment for allowing their rifle to hit the deck. Also used when a Marine drops anything. * '''Form ID-10T''' or '''ID-Ten-Tango''' – Pejorative for "[[Idiot (usage)|idiot]]". * '''''Fortitudine''''' – Former motto of the Marine Corps in the 19th century (replaced by [[Semper fidelis|Semper Fidelis]]), from the [[Latin]] word for "fortitude"; also the name of the Marine Corps History Division's quarterly magazine. * '''Four Fingers of Death''' – Nickname for the ill famed [[Sausage|frankfurter]] MRE (Meals-Ready-to-Eat) with four small hot dogs as the main meal [[MRE]]<ref>http://www.judithmiller.com/6541/military-food</ref> * '''[[Defensive fighting position|Foxhole]]''' – Fighting hole as termed by the Army and Marines of the past, no longer appropriate for Marine use. "Fighting hole," "firing hole," and "Forward Firing Position" should be considered. There is a difference between 1 MARDIV and 2 MARDIV{{clarify|date=March 2015}}. * '''FRAGO''' – FRAGmentary Order, an addendum to published operational orders. * '''FRO''' – Family Readiness Officer * '''[[Frocking|Frock]]''' – To be authorized to wear the next higher grade before promotion, confers authority but not pay grade. * '''Frock You''' – Response to an inappropriate request to be promoted to a Marine's selected rank, ahead of their scheduled promotion. * '''[[FUBAR]]''' – Fucked/Fouled Up Beyond All Recognition/Repair. * '''FUBIJAR''' – Fuck yoU Buddy, I'm Just A Reservist.<ref>[http://www.maritimequest.com/misc_pages/slang_terms/slang_f.htm Military Abbreviations, Nicknames and Slang Terms] on MaritimeQuest.com</ref><ref>[http://www.bearwatch.net/index.php? option=com_content&task=view&id=33&Itemid=122 Military Slang] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204190904/http://bearwatch.net/index.php |date=2009-02-04 }} on BearWatch.net</ref> * '''Full-Bird''' – [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]], as opposed to a [[#H|half-bird]], [[#L|light-colonel]], or [[#S|short-bird / short colonel]], [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|Lieutenant Colonel]]; so named because his or her rank insignia is a silver eagle.
==G== * '''G-2''' – An individual's [[Intelligence|intellect]], from designation for a [[staff (military)#Intelligence / security / information operations (2)|staff intelligence organization]]. * '''[[wikt:gaff|Gaff]] Off''' – To disregard or ignore a person or order, context usually denotes insubordination.<ref>[http://onlineslangdictionary.com/definition+of/gaff+off gaff off] on Online Slang Dictionary</ref><ref>[http://www.diclib.com/cgi-bin/d1.cgi? l=en&base=amslang&page=showid&id=3848 gaff off] on Dictionary of American Slang</ref> * '''Gagglefuck''' – Group of Marines grouped too closely or in an unorganized fashion; from [[wikt:gaggle|gaggle]], the term for a flock of grounded geese, and [[#C|clusterfuck]], a term for a messy situation. * '''[[wikt:gangway|Gangway]]''' – Ship's passageway; also used to order juniors to give way to seniors in passageways, and particularly when going up and down ladders. * '''[[Garrison]]''' – In addition to the traditional meaning, an adjective referring to not being deployed or deployable, such as buildings at a unit's home base. * '''Garrison Cover''' – Soft green folded cap worn with the [[Uniforms of the United States Marine Corps#Service uniform|service uniform]]. See also [[#F|fore-and-aft cap]] and [[#P|piss cover/cutter]]. * '''Gate Fishing''' – An off-duty Marine who chats up a girl who may or may not be loitering outside the main gate of Yokosuka, Naval Base (Late 1990s era). * '''Gear''' – Property or equipment; usually referring to an individual's combat equipment. * '''Gear Adrift''' – Gear found left lying around or unguarded, from the saying "gear adrift, must be a gift!". * '''[[Gedunk|Geedunk]]''' – Candy and other sweets, or a location where such items are obtained (such as a store or [[vending machine]]); borrowed from the comic strip [[Harold Teen]].<ref>[http://archives.stupidquestion.net/sq52404.html geedunk] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080915182836/http://archives.stupidquestion.net/sq52404.html |date=September 15, 2008 }} on stupidquestions.net</ref> See also [[#P|pogey bait]]. * '''[[General officers in the United States|General]]''' – One method of addressing a [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]], [[Major general (United States)|Major General]], [[Lieutenant general (United States)|Lieutenant General]], or [[General (United States)|General]]. The other would be either "Sir" or Ma'am." * '''General Orders''' – List of 11 [[General Orders for Sentries]] detailing rules for guard or sentry duty. * '''Get Some''' – Spirited cry expressing approval and the desire for more or to continue, traditionally associated in the [[Vietnam War]] to killing or sex. * '''[[G.I. (military)|GI]] Shower''' – Bathing with limited water (often with the use of [[wet wipe]]s); forcibly bathing an individual who refuses to meet minimum hygiene standards.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/gi-shower GI shower] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> * '''GITMO''' – [[Guantanamo Bay Naval Base|U.S. Naval Base, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba]]. * '''Glow Belt''' – A reflective belt used when running on or near hard-surfaced roads that makes pedestrians more visible to motorists. * '''Go-fasters''' – [[Running shoes]] or sneakers, named so because they help a person run faster than boots.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} * '''[[wikt:goat rope|Goat Rope]]''' – A chaotic and messy situation.<ref>[http://www.doubletongued.org/index.php/dictionary/goat_rope/ Goa-rope] on [[Double-Tongued Dictionary]]</ref> See also [[#C|cluster fuck]]. * '''Going High and to the Right''' – losing one's temper or rationality; from the common error of a poor shooter to jerk the trigger and impact the upper right side of a target. * '''Gomer''' or '''GOMER''' – Antiquated slang for a stupid person, from the character [[Gomer Pyle]]; or as a [[backronym]] for "Get Out of My Emergency Room" used by [[hospital corpsman|corpsmen]] to refer to [[malingering|malingerers]] who faked illness to avoid duties. * '''Good Cookie''' – [[Good Conduct Medal (United States)|Good Conduct Medal]]. * '''Good to Go''' – Expression denoting that difficulties will be overcome; ready; well done or satisfactory.<ref>[http://idioms.thefreedictionary.com/good+to+go good to go] on [[TheFreeDictionary.com]]</ref> * '''[[Gook]]''' – Anything foreign or strange.<ref>Tregaskis, ''Guadalcanal Diary'', 113.</ref> In modern US usage, "gook" refers particularly to Communist soldiers during the Vietnam War. It is generally considered to be highly offensive and viewed as a racial slur. * '''[[Gore-Tex]]''' – All Purpose Environmental Clothing System (APECS), a cold/wet weather protective parka and trousers, based on the [[Extended Cold Weather Clothing System]], usually in reference to the parka; from the fabric it is made from.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marcorsyscom.usmc.mil/SITES/PMICE/InfoPapers/Clothing/APECS.pdf |title=APECS data sheet |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212205430/http://www.marcorsyscom.usmc.mil/SITES/PMICE/InfoPapers/Clothing/APECS.pdf |archivedate=2012-02-12 |df= }}</ref>
* '''Gouge''' – Information or news. See also [[#W|word]]. * '''Grab-Ass''' – Horseplay, usually wrestling.<ref name="vetfriends.com"/> * '''Grand Old Man of the Marine Corps''' – Usually refers to [[Archibald Henderson|Brevet Brigadier General Archibald Henderson]]. * '''Grape''' – A Marine's head, as in: "Keep on grab assing and you're going to fall and bust your grape!" * '''Greens''' – [[Uniforms of the United States Marine Corps#Service uniform|service uniforms]] in reference to their color.
[[File:USMC-E7.svg|thumb|150px|[[Gunnery Sergeant|Gunny]]]]
* '''Grid Squares''' – Marked [[Geographic coordinate system|reference lines]] on a map; often used as a prank [[Snipe hunt|fool's errand]] where an unsuspecting Marine is asked to find a box of them when they don't physically exist. * '''Grinder''' – [[#P|parade ground or deck]] used primarily for drill or formations.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/grinder grinder] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> * '''Ground Guide''' – A person who walks in front of a vehicle in order to detect and avoid obstacles and guide the driver to the proper spot.<ref> [https://crc.army.mil/drivertrainingtoolbox/docs/Sample_Drivers_Training_Program/DT_Program_Lesson_Plans_Exams/Classroom_Trn_Phase_II/Lesson_6_Ground_Guide/Ground_Guiding.ppt Training presentation for ground guiding]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
* '''[[wikt:grunt|Grunt]]''' or '''Ground Pounder''' – [[Infantry]]man, formerly a pejorative that has taken more neutral tones. * '''GT Score''' – Intelligence, from the General Technical score on the [[Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery]] and the minimum scores that many [[Military Occupational Specialties]] require to qualify.<ref>[http://www.blurtit.com/q297027.html GT Score] on blurtit.com</ref>
* '''Guide''' – Unit [[Guidon (United States)|guidon]]-bearer; in [[recruit training]], also the senior recruit and responsible for the actions of all recruits in a platoon.<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Guidon& guidon] on [[Reference.com]]</ref> * '''Gumby Suit''' – Two pieced wet weather gear consisting of a hooded jacket and overalls used until the mid-1990s when the Gore-Tex replaced it. So named because it is green in color and the wearers tended to look like the character Gumby. Those who have worn them can remember its distinctive rubber cloth odor. '''Gumby Suits''' can still be found for purchase at military surplus stores. * '''Gun Bunny''' – [[Artillery]]man. See also [[#C|cannon cocker]] and [[#R|red leg]]. Also refers to a Marine unit's Armorers, as they spend long hours inside the armory conducting maintenance on weapons. * '''Gun Club''' – slang term for the [[USMC]] at-large as in "I've been in this gun club longer than you." Use in presence of senior personnel is inappropriate. Use by civilians or members of other services is considered disrespectful. * '''Gun Doc''' - Nickname for a 2111 SART or 2131 TAST * '''[[Gung-ho|Gung ho]]''' – Chinese phrase meaning to "work together," it became the battle cry of the [[Marine Raiders]]. * '''Gunner''' – shortened form of Marine Gunner, a nickname for an [[Infantry Weapons Officer]]; used informally to refer to all [[Warrant officer (United States)#Marine Corps|warrant officer]] ranks. * '''Gunny''' – Nickname for [[Gunnery Sergeant]], improper to call a [[Master Gunnery Sergeant]] this.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/gunny-marine-lingo gunny] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> * '''Gyrene''' – Nickname for a Marine, considered to be a grievous insult; combination of the words "[[G.I. (military)|GI]]" and "Marine".<ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/gyrene gyrene] on [[Merriam-Webster]] online</ref><ref> [http://www.thefreedictionary.com/gyrene gyrene] on [[TheFreeDictionary.com]]</ref>
==H==
[[File:US halfstaff sunset.jpg|thumb|150px|[[half-staff|half-mast]]]]
* '''H&S''' – [[Headquarters (military)|Headquarters]] & Service/Supply [[company (military unit)|Company]], much like a [[List of United States Marine Corps battalions#Headquarters battalions|Headquarters Battalion]]. * '''hack''' – [[arrest]]. * '''[[Hajji|Haji]]''' (hah-jee) – [[Arab]] or [[Middle East]]ern person or object, from the [[Arabic language|Arabic]] term for one who has completed a [[pilgrimage]] to [[Mecca]], or "''[[hajj]]''" * '''Half-bird''' – [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|Lieutenant Colonel]], as opposed to a [[#F|full-bird]]. See also [[#S|short colonel]]. * '''[[Half-Staff|Half-Mast]]''' – position of the ensign when hoisted to one flag/ensign height below the top, usually done in respect to a deceased person; also called "half-staff" among non-naval forces. Half-Mast is also a term used by aircraft personnel and aircrew, describing the wearing of the flight suits and coveralls (a one piece uniform) rolled down to the waist so as to look like pants. * '''Hard Charger''' or '''Hard''' – term of endearment from a senior to a junior Marine when he or she completes a difficult task, so named for charging through the assignment; or general toughness. * '''Hashmark''' – [[service stripe]] worn on the uniform sleeve by enlisted men and women for completion of four years of honorable service in any of the U.S. Armed Services and Reserves. * '''[[wikt:hatch|Hatch]]''' – Door; more specifically, the watertight cover over an opening between compartments or that leads to the [[#L|ladder wells]] between decks of a ship. * '''HBT''' – [[Herringbone (cloth)|HerringBone]] [[Twill]]; the cotton material of Marine utilities from 1941 to the late 1950s. * '''HDR''' – Humanitarian Daily Ration, a variation of the [[Meal, Ready-to-Eat|MRE]] used to feed a single malnourished person for one day with 2,300 calories. * '''HE''' – [[Explosive material|High Explosive]], used to describe various kinds of [[Ammunition|ordnance]], or Heavy Equipment.
[[File:US Navy 090719-N-5253W-074 Marine Staff Sgt. William McGowan, right, and Marine Cpl. Thomas Down, both assigned to Marine Medium Helicopter Squadron (HMM) 262, look down through the.jpg|thumb|150px|looking out the hell hole]]
* '''[[Head (watercraft)|head]]''' – [[bathroom]] or [[latrine]], a nautical term from the days of sailing ships when the designated place to defecate and urinate was forward, at the [[Bow (ship)|bow]] or "head" of the ship. * '''Head Shed''' – [[Command post]] or other headquarters area where senior Marines gather. * '''Headgear''' – Hats, helmets, caps, etc. * '''HEAT''' – [[High-explosive anti-tank warhead|High-Explosive AntiTank]], type of tank round. * '''Heavy Hat''' – Second-most senior [[drill instructor]] in a platoon. <!-- hell hole image above --> * '''Hell Hole''' – Hatch mounted in the deck of many helicopters (such as the [[CH-53E Super Stallion]]) for [[Abseiling|rappeling]] and cargo lifting. * '''Helo''' – [[Helicopter]]. "Chopper" is an Army term. * '''HEDP''' – High-Explosive Dual Purpose, type of [[Armor-piercing shot and shell|armor-piercing]] ammunition. * '''Hershey Bars''' – Black leather dress shoes that required regular polishing. Thrown out by most Marines after boot camp and replaced with corfams. * '''Hidin' and Slidin'''' – pejorative backronym for H&S (Headquarters and Service) companies. Also "Hotdogs and Soda." * '''[[High and tight|High and Tight]]''' – Nickname for a common variant of the [[buzz cut]], where the hair is clipped very close. Although having become heavily associated with Marines (giving rise to the term "jarhead"), it's generally not the most common or preferred haircut worn among most Fleet Marines. Also referred to as a "High reg(ular)." * "'''Higher-ups'''" – Nickname for Marines above the rank of E-5 Sergeant. * '''High-speed''' – New, interesting, or cool; often used to sarcastically denote that the subject looks good, but performance is dubious. * '''[[Hillbilly Armor]]''' – [[improvised vehicle armour|improvised vehicle armor]]. * '''HIMARS''' – [[High Mobility Artillery Rocket System]]. * '''Hippity-hop, mob stop!''' – Used in place of "Platoon, halt!" by a drill instructor displeased with a platoon's drill performance. * '''HMMWV''' or '''Humvee''' – [[High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle|High-Mobility Multi-purpose Wheeled Vehicle]], common utility vehicle. * '''Hollywood Marine''' – Marine who has graduated from [[Marine Corps Recruit Depot San Diego]], stemming from rivalry between the two recruit depots (the other being [[Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island]]). * '''Homeslice''' – Person, often a sarcastic overture to civilians from a [[drill instructor]]; from the terms [[homie]] and homeboy. * '''Homesteading''' – Remaining at one duty station for an extended tour or consecutive tours. * '''[[wiktionary:honcho|Honcho]]''' or '''[[wiktionary:head honcho|Head Honcho]]''' – Person in charge, from the [[Japanese language|Japanese]] word for "boss', "''hanchō''"; also a nickname for [[Okinawa Island|Okinawa]]n taxi drivers. * '''Hooch''' – Field living quarters. Also tied into the term [[Hooch maid]], which referred to a woman in Vietnam who would clean the dwellings of soldiers, which were deemed "hooches." * '''Hot-Shit''' – Sarcastic reference to an overly arrogant person. * '''Horse-cock Sandwich''' – Any sandwich or meal created using an unknown or mystery meat. Often, specifically, sliced balogna. Occasionally served as breakfast meat. * '''House Mouse''' – Recruit tasked with cleaning and performing domestic chores in drill instructor-only areas. See also [[#D|DI hut]]. * '''Housewife''' – [[Girlfriend]]; also [[sewing]] kit. * '''HQMC''' – [[Headquarters Marine Corps]]. * '''[[wiktionary:hump#Verb|Hump]]''' – Carry or lift a load, originally an [[Australia]]n term meaning "to carry one's [[swag (bedroll)|swag]],"; also a [[Loaded march|forced march carrying full equipment loads]]. * '''Hurry up and wait''' – Expression denoting inefficient time management or planning, often when a senior rushes a unit into a situation too fast that subsequently makes them wait. This can refer to the period between receiving a Warning Order and actually implementing an Operations Order. * '''Huss''' – To give a helping hand, so named because the [[Sikorsky H-34|H-34 Choctaw]] helicopter's utility configuration was designated as the "HUS-1 Seahorse," leading to Vietnam-era Marines that needed a medical evacuation helicopter to ask for or to be "cut a huss".
==I==
* '''IAW''' – In Accordance With, term often used to denote compliance with published orders or procedures. * '''IG''' – [[Inspector General]]. * '''ILBE''' – [[Improved Load Bearing Equipment]], the newest iteration of personal combat gear, utilizes the [[Pouch Attachment Ladder System|PALS]], replaced [[MOLLE (military)|MOLLE]]. * '''In Country''' – Phrase referring to being within a war zone. * '''Incentive/Individual Training''' or '''IT''' – Physical training used as a punishment, especially in recruit training, sometimes nicknamed "incentive torture," "indoor tennis," or getting "thrashed/bent/slayed/destroyed" by recruits.<ref>{{cite book|last=Tomajczyk|first=Stephen F.|title=To Be a U.S. Marine|publisher=Zenith Imprint|year=2004|page=41|isbn=0-7603-1788-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GpdR4kH89jAC&pg=PA41&lpg=PA41&dq=%22incentive+training%22+marine&source=bl&ots=QjcWL0awdm&sig=HaNigUl_dW3pySmgp0JhLUS_bOc&hl=en&ei=tagGSoe_AoWT_QaE79CQBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4}}</ref><ref>[http://www.marines.cc/content/view/32/33/ DI and Incentive Training] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060113182029/http://www.marines.cc/content/view/32/33/ |date=2006-01-13 }} on Marines.cc</ref><ref>[http://www.faqs.org/abstracts/Military-and-naval-science/Incentive-training-for-Marine-recruits-an-extra-push-can-make-a-world-of-difference.html incentive training] on [[Internet FAQ Consortium]]</ref> See also [[#P|pitting]] & [[#Q|quarterdecking]]. * '''Inkstick''' – [[Pen]]<ref name="Jarheadbook"/> * '''Irish Pennant''' or '''IP''' – Any loose thread, string, or strap on a uniform or equipment that detracts from a perfect appearance. * '''[[Iron Mike]]''' – Originally a nautical term for a [[gyrocompass]]; name for various memorial statues, such as at [[Iron Mike#Parris Island, South Carolina|Parris Island, SC]], [[Iron Mike#Quantico, Virginia|Quantico, VA]], and [[Iron Mike#Belleau, France|Belleau, France]]; nickname bestowed on Marines who score a perfect 300 points on the [[United States Marine Corps Physical Fitness Test|Physical Fitness Test]]; nickname for a [[Company (military unit)|company]] or [[Artillery battery|battery]] named "M or "Mike" in [[ICAO spelling alphabet|NATO phonetic alphabet]]. * '''IRR''' – [[Individual Ready Reserve]], branch of the [[Reserve component of the Armed Forces of the United States|reserve]] that most former servicemembers fall under upon the end of active service, may be called to involuntarily return to active status.
==J==
* '''JAG''' – [[United States Marine Corps Judge Advocate Division|Judge Advocate General]], colloquial name for the legal entity within the Marine Corps, more properly called '''Judge Advocate Division''', from the [[Judge Advocate General of the Navy]], the naval officer who oversees both the Navy's and Marine Corps' legal entities; also, a [[JAG (TV series)|television show]] by the same name. * '''Jarhead''' – Pejorative term for a Marine. Jarhead has several supposed origins: the regulation "High and Tight" haircut resembles a [[mason jar]] (to add insult, some note that the jar is an empty vessel, also therefore a Marine's head an empty vessel); the [[John Landis Mason|Mason Jar Company]] stopped making jars and made the helmets for Marines during [[World War II]]. * '''JAX''' – Jacksonville, North Carolina. Located outside Camp Lejeune. Also called J-ville. Typical US military town filled with bars/taverns, pawn shops, tattoo parlors, car dealers and strip clubs. More commonly referred to as J-ville. * '''[[Jesus]] slippers''' or '''Jesus boots''' – Government-issue sandals or flip-flops for sanitation in showers. Also known as a "Boot from the Heavens". "Best boot I ever had". See also [[#S|shower shoes]]. * '''JETDS''' – [[Joint Electronics Type Designation System]], used to categorize the [[Naming convention|nomenclature]] of electronic equipment. *'''JEW''' – Junior enlisted warrior, E-3 and below. * '''JJ DID TIE BUCKLE''' – [[Mnemonic]] for the 14 leadership traits: [[Justice]], [[Judgement]], [[Dependability]], [[Initiative (organization)|Initiative]], [[wikt:decisiveness|Decisiveness]], [[Tact (psychology)|Tact]], [[Integrity]], [[Enthusiasm]], [[wikt:bearing|Bearing]], [[altruism|Unselfishness]], [[Courage]], [[Knowledge]], [[Loyalty]], [[Endurance]].
[[File:P-38 Can Opener.jpg|thumb|150px|[[P-38 can opener|John Wayne]]]]
* '''JOB''' – [[Junk On the Bunk]], a formal inspection of gear that takes place in the squad bay where the gear is placed on the rack in a predesignated order. Also known as 'Things On the Springs'.
<!-- John Wayne image above --> * '''John Wayne''' – [[P-38 can opener]], a small folding blade used to open canned rations (such as [[K-ration]]s or [[C-ration]]s), so named because [[John Wayne|the actor]] was shown in a training film using it. * '''Joker''' – Military [[journalist]], from [[Full Metal Jacket#Cast and characters|Private Joker]] from the movie [[Full Metal Jacket]]; also a derogatory term for a junior enlisted servicemember. Also, used by aviators, the time at which only 60 minutes of fuel remain. * '''Jungle Bunny''' – [[Vietnam War]]–era phrase for [[infantry]]. * '''Junk on [the] Bunk''' – Inspection where all uniforms and equipment to be displayed is laid on the Marine's [[#R|rack]].
==K==
[[File:KA-BAR.jpg|thumb|150px|[[KA-BAR]]]] * '''K''' or '''[[Klick (unit of length)|klick]]s''' – Kilometer. * '''[[KA-BAR]]''' – Fighting/utility knife first issued during [[World War II]]. * '''K-Bay''' – [[Marine Corps Base Hawaii]]. * '''Keeper''' – Cloth loop on the [[Uniforms of the United States Marine Corps#Service uniform|green service blouse]] to hold the cloth belt neatly in place. * '''Kelly Helmet''' or '''K-pot''' – [[Brodie helmet|1917-model basin helmet]] worn during [[World War I]] until 1942. * '''Kevlar''' – [[Helmet]] made from [[kevlar]]. * '''Keyboard Jockey''' – Person whose job causes him or her use a computer for a length of time. * '''Kill''' – A positive affirmation. * '''Kill Hat''' – A junior [[Drill Instructor]] who specializes in discipline and punishment. See also [[#H|heavy hat]]. * '''Kin Town''' – A small town located just outside Camp Hansen, Okinawa. Also called Kinville or Sinville. Great place to get Taco rice and cheese and Yakisoba. *'''Kit''' – another term for the old wb gear (LBE) when it included the butt-pack. *'''Knowledge''' - Book. * '''Kuni''' – [[Marine Corps Air Station Iwakuni]].
==L==
* Lad – term that came out of WW I for a young Marine. * '''Ladder Well''' – [[Stairway]] or [[ladder]] connecting different decks of a ship, so named because naval stairs tend to be so steep as to almost be vertical. * '''[[Laminate]]d''' – Perceived semi-permanent state of issue for a normally temporary status. * '''Lance Colonel''' – Derivation of [[Lance corporal#Marine Corps|Lance Corporal]] denoting a junior Marine with extended time in service or grade. See also [[#T|terminal lance]]. * '''Lance Coolie''', '''Lance Criminal''', or '''Lance Coconut''' – derogatory terms for [[Lance corporal#Marine Corps|Lance Corporal]]. * '''Lance Corporal Underground''' or '''Lance Corporal Network''' – Joking reference to the gulf between non-NCOs and their superiors; also refers to the spread of foolish [[rumor]]s that a more experienced Marine would immediately recognize as false.<ref> [http://www.lancecorporalofmarines.com/Lance_Corporal_of_Marines/LCOM_Association_%7C_About_Us.html Lance Corporal of Marines Association] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080802004109/http://www.lancecorporalofmarines.com/Lance_Corporal_of_Marines/LCOM_Association_%7C_About_Us.html |date=2008-08-02 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.leatherneck.com/forums/archive/index.php/t-54149.html Lance Corporal Underground] on leatherneck.com</ref>
* '''Landing Gear''' – Crossed rifles exposed on the rank insignia of [[Lance corporal#Marine Corps|Lance Corporal]]s, [[Corporal#United States Marine Corps|Corporal]]s, and [[Sergeant#Marine Corps|Sergeant]]s. * '''Land of the big PX''' – Used in reference to [[CONUS]] by Marines deployed overseas. * '''[[Lawn Dart]]''' – Pejorative for various aircraft, possibly from the [[lawn dart effect]].<ref name="lawndart">{{cite web|url=http://www.pulitzer.org/archives/6722|title=Far From Battlefield, Marines Lose One-Third of Harrier Fleet|author=Alan C. Miller & Kevin Sack|date=December 15, 2002|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|accessdate=2009-03-16}}</ref> * '''LBV''' – Load Bearing [[Vest]], personal equipment used to keep the most commonly used items within easy reach utilizing the [[Pouch Attachment Ladder System|PALS]], usually a component of [[MOLLE (military)|MOLLE]] or [[Improved Load Bearing Equipment|ILBE]]. * '''LCPLIC''' – Lance Corporal in Charge. A salty Lance Corporal.
<!-- leatherneck image above --> * '''[[Leatherneck]]''' – Nickname for Marine, so named for legends stating that stiff leather collars were once worn to protect the throat from sword-blows (also thought that high stocks were worn for discipline, to keep Marines' heads high and straight). The [[Uniforms of the United States Marine Corps#Dress uniform|dress blue uniform]] still bears a high stock collar today. Also, [[Leatherneck Magazine]]. * '''Leg''' – Servicemember who does not rate to wear the [[Parachutist Badge (United States)#Navy & Marine Corps|Parachutist Insignia]], borrowed from the Army [[XVIII Airborne Corps (United States)|Airborne]]. * '''[[Leggings#Military use|leggings]]''' – Leg coverings made of canvas with eyelets and laces or buckles to secure the trouser legs over [[Trench boot|boots]].<ref name="leggings">[http://www.answers.com/topic/leggings leggings] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> * '''Liberty''' – Authorized free time ashore or off station, not counted as [[Leave (military)|leave]], known in the Army as a "pass". * '''Liberty List''' – List containing the names of Marines entitled to liberty and those employed by the guard during the liberty period (and thus not entitled to leave post). *'''Liberty Risk''' – A Marine with a high risk of getting into trouble on liberty. * '''Lifer''' – Career servicemember, as opposed to one who serves for a single enlistment. * '''Lima Charlie''' or '''Lickin' Chicken''' – Loud and Clear, an expression meaning that the communication has been received and understood; originally exclusive to [[radio]] traffic. * '''Line Company''' – Lettered Marine [[company (military unit)|companies]] or the aviation term for ground units, originally, an infantry company.
{{double image|right|US-OF1A.svg|75|USMC CWO3.svg|58|1st Lt (''left'') and Chief Warrant Officer 3 (''right'') insignias}}
* '''Lipstick Lieutenant''' – Pejorative for [[Warrant officer (United States)#Marine Corps|warrant officer]], so named from the appearance of their [[Warrant officer (United States)#Modern insignia and grades|rank insignia]]: the addition of red to the gold and silver bars of a [[lieutenant]].<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/lipstick-lieutenant lipstick lieutenant] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> * '''Lollygag''' – Dawdle or fool about. * '''Long Handles''' – Long sleeved/legged undershirt/shorts. * '''[[War on Terror#Language|Long War]]''' – Term for the [[War on Terrorism]] favored by senior military leaders. * '''Lost Lieutenant Finder''' – Hand-held [[Global Positioning System|GPS]] unit, a joke term on the reputation for new lieutenants to be incompetent in land [[navigation]]. * '''LPCs''' – Abbreviation for Leather Personnel Carriers, aka combat boots * '''LPD''' – Abbreviation for Landing Platform/Dock, aka [[Amphibious transport dock]] * '''LT''' – Abbreviation for [[lieutenant]], inappropriate to address as such verbally. * '''LWH''' – [[Lightweight Helmet|LightWeight Helmet]]. * '''LZ''' – [[Landing Zone]], a clearing designated as the place where a [[helicopter]] (or other [[VTOL]] aircraft) can land.
==M==
* '''M''' – A prefix to the model number of a specific nomenclature of equipment, generally considered to denote "model" or "[[Mark (designation)|mark]]". Also us in the phonetic alphabet for "Mike". * '''Ma'am''' – Proper method of addressing female officers. * '''Mac Marine''' – Nickname for Marine, popular during [[World War II]], also the career planner popular on posters of the 1960s. * '''Mad Max''' – term for a military vehicle that is irregular in appearance due to repairs, modifications or the presence of extra equipment. See also [[#H|hillbilly armor]]. * '''Maggie's Drawers''' – Red flag attached to a pole, used to signal a miss on the rifle range, replaced by a red disk. * '''MAGTF''' – [[Marine Air-Ground Task Force]]. * '''MAGTFery''' – I.e., "Mag-taf-ery." Anything associated with MAGTF-type operations, or the unique structure of the Marine Corps MAGTF.
[[File:USMC-E9-MGyS.svg|thumb|150px|[[Master Gunnery Sergeant|Master Guns]]]]
* '''Major''' – A [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]] in command of a ship's Marine detachment, so titled because a ship may have only one [[Captain (United States O-6)|Captain]], the commanding officer. * '''Mama-san''' – Term of endearment for an elder [[Japan]]ese woman, often a maid, cook, or tailor/seamstress performing services for Marines; from the Japanese honorific "''[[Japanese titles#San|san]]''". * '''MARINE''' – Muscles Are Required, Intelligence Non-Essential or My Ass Really Is Navy Equipment, pejorative [[backronym]]s used by other branches. * '''Marine''' – The following nicknames are usually acceptable: leatherneck, devil dog, sea soldier, warrior, hard charger, motivator; the following are acceptable from other Marines: jarhead, gyrene; the following are grievous insults: soldier, seabag. * '''Marine house''' – [[Marine Corps Security Guard|Security Guard]] term for living quarters for Marines, on or off [[Diplomatic mission|embassy]] grounds.
<!-- Master Guns image above --> * '''Master Guns''' or '''Master Gunny''' – [[Master Gunnery Sergeant]]. Also sometimes referred to as "Maverick" due to the combination of slang for Master Sergeant "Top" and Gunnery Sergeant "Gunny". *'''Marine Mattress''' – A woman who is thought to be sexually promiscuous with other Marines. The plural form is colloquially referred to as M&Ms. *'''MATMEP''' – Maintenance Training Management and Evaluation Program. Used to document individual formal and informal training in 6XXX series occupations (i.e., aviation maintenance); this information then rolls up to show an aviation unit's overall readiness to sustain operations. Sometimes referred to as "Me And The Marines Enjoy Paperwork" from the voluminous amounts of documentation generated. * '''MCI''' – [[Marine Corps Institute]], a [[distance education]] program; also, the courses available to Marines for bonus promotion credit. * '''MCCS''' – '''M'''arine '''C'''orps '''C'''ommunity '''S'''ervices (also known by the humorous [[backronym]] '''M'''arine '''C'''orps '''C'''rime '''S'''yndicate) * '''MCMAP, MCNinja''' – [[Marine Corps Martial Arts Program]]. * '''MCT''' – [[Camp Geiger#Marine Combat Training (MCT)|Marine Combat Training]], [[infantry]] skills training for non-infantry Marines. * '''MCSF''' – Marine Corps Security Forces (Company) usually a company size unit assigned to the security of Naval assets. MOS 8152, MCSF School is at NSGA Northwest VA, and due to the intense marksmanship training Marines are known as 'Gunslingers', Marine Corps Super Friends. * '''Meat Gazer''' – [[Urinalysis]] observer who observes the servicemember peeing into the sample container to prevent tampering with the sample. * '''MEB''' – [[Marine Expeditionary Brigade]]. * '''MEDEVAC''' or '''Medivac''' – [[Medical evacuation|MEDical EVACuation]], removing a wounded person to the closest medical or [[triage]] facility using designated [[ambulance]] equipment, vehicles, or aircraft. See also [[#C|CASEVAC]]. * '''Med Float Widow''' – Unfaithful wife of a Marine or Sailor deployed from the East Coast on a '''float''' a.k.a. '''float widow''' * '''MEF''' – [[Marine Expeditionary Force]]. * '''MEPS''' – [[United States Military Entrance Processing Command|Military Entrance Processing Station]], facility where prospective recruits are screened medically, psychologically, and legally for [[recruit training]]. * '''Mess Hall''' – [[Cafeteria]]. See also [[#C|chow hall]]. * '''Messman''' – [[Chef|cook]]. * '''MEU''' – [[Marine Expeditionary Unit]]. * '''MEU(SOC)''' – Marine Expeditionary Unit (Special Operations Capable); 11th MEU(SOC), 13th MEU(SOC), 15th MEU(SOC), 22nd MEU(SOC), 24th MEU(SOC), 26th MEU(SOC) or 31st MEU(SOC). * '''[[Mickey Mouse]] Boots''' – Boots designed for extreme cold weather using an air bladder for insulation, so named for their oversized and bloated appearance. * '''Midrats''' – Midnight (or other late-night) rations provided for servicemembers who work late hours.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/midrats midrats] on [[Answers.com]]</ref> * '''Mike''' – [[Minute]]. * '''Mike-mike''' – Millimeter. * '''Military Left''' – Pertaining to the left side of something or the direction to the left of the subject in question. Used sarcastically when giving orders when a subordinate turns the wrong way or is unsure of which way to turn. * '''Military Right''' – Pertaining to the right side of something or the direction to the right of the subject in question. Used sarcastically when giving orders when a subordinate turns the wrong way or is unsure of which way to turn. * '''[[Military Time]]''' – The time of day on a [[24-hour clock]]. General [[Wallace M. Greene]] forbade the practice of suffixing the unnecessary word "hours" after each indication of time of day ("1330" or "thirteen-thirty" instead of "1330 hours"); the practice of saying "oh" instead of "zero" for hours before 1000 has diminished as well.
[[File:MOPP 4 high res.JPEG|thumb|150px|[[MOPP]] equipment]]
* '''MOLLE''' – [[MOLLE (military)|MOdular Lightweight Load-carrying Equipment]], type of load-bearing equipment utilizing the [[Pouch Attachment Ladder System|PALS]], replaced [[All-purpose Lightweight Individual Carrying Equipment|ALICE]] and replaced by [[Improved Load Bearing Equipment|ILBE]]. * '''Molly Marine''' – Nickname associated with World War II era female Marines. Also the name of the award given to the top ranking female Marine in her recruit platoon. * '''Monkey Suit''' – Slang for the MARPAT uniform, otherwise known as digital cammies. * '''Moonbeam''' – [[flashlight]].
<!-- MOPP suit image above --> * '''MOPP''' – [[MOPP|Mission Oriented Protective Posture]], or an out-of-date term for the defense equipment ([[gas masks]] and overgarment suits) worn to protect against [[weapon of mass destruction|Nuclear, Biological, and Chemical weapons]]. * '''Mosquito Wings''' or '''Skeeter Wings''' – Rank insignia for a [[Private first class#United States Marine Corps|Private First Class]], a single chevron. * '''Motivator''' – Term of endearment from a senior to a junior Marine, so named when the junior displays [[motivation]] for his or her duties. * '''Moto''' – [[Motivation|Motivated/motivating]], often used to describe a person, object, or event that would motivate an individual Marine. * '''Moto Tats''' – tattoos displaying USMC logos or slogans, often gotten by young Marines right out of basic training, that are looked upon as being overly gratuitous and boastful. * '''Motarded''' – Displaying excess [[motivation]], often in the form of visual symbols and lore (such as unit logos); a combination of the terms "moto" and "[[mental retardation|retarded]]". * '''Motor T''' or '''MT''' – Motor Transport, a subunit of Marines responsible for the operation and maintenance of wheeled non-combat and non-engineer vehicles. * '''MOUT''' – [[Urban warfare|Military Operation in Urban Terrain]]. See also [[#C|CQB/CQC]]. * '''[[Military Occupational Specialty|MOS]]''' – Military Occupational Specialty, a job classification. * '''MP''' – [[Military police#United States|Military Police]], mostly replaced by [[#P|PMO]]. * '''MRE''' – [[Meal, Ready-to-Eat]], standard U.S. [[field ration]]. Sometimes jokingly referred to with [[backronym]]s such as "Meals Rejected by the Enemy," "Meals Rejected by [[Ethiopia]]," "Meal, Rotten to [[vomiting|Eject]]," "Meals Rarely Eaten," "Meal, Refusing to Exit," "Meal, Reluctant to Exit," "Mister E," or the "Three Lies for the Price of One". * '''MRE bomb''' – Bursting plastic bag made from chemical heating pouches found inside of a standard MRE. * '''MSG''' – [[Marine Corps Security Guard]], responsible for guarding [[Diplomatic missions of the United States|United States Embassies]]. * '''MTO''' – Motor Transport Officer, the Marine in charge of maintenance and operation of a unit's [[truck]]s. * '''MTV''' – [[Modular Tactical Vest]], the newest type of [[ballistic vest]] for Marines. * '''MTVR''' – [[Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement]] See also [[#0–9|7-ton]]. * '''Mustang/Mustanger''' – Marine Officer who has previously served in the enlisted ranks. * '''Muster''' (Gather) – formal gathering of troops, especially for inspection, display, or exercise. * '''MWD''' – [[War dog|Military Working Dog]], a trained government [[Dog|canine]] for law enforcement, [[Detection dog|detection]] of explosives or drugs, [[Guard dog|sentry]], or other military use(s). * '''Mystery Meat''' – A low quality unknown type of meat patty served at Marine Corps Recruit Depot San Diego.
==N== [[File:NCIS Logo.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Naval Criminal Investigative Service|NCIS]] logo]]
* '''NAVY''' – Never Again Volunteer Yourself, Never Actually Ventures Yonder, pejorative [[backronym]] used by sailors who regret volunteering or are otherwise dissatisfied with their post. * '''NBCD''' – Nuclear, Biological, Chemical Defense. See also [[#C|CBRN]]. Need Bitches Call, No Body Cares. * '''NCIS''' – [[Naval Criminal Investigative Service]], the primary law enforcement agency of the [[United States Department of the Navy|DoN]], also a [[NCIS (TV series)|television show of the same name]]. * '''NCO''' – [[Non-commissioned officer]]: [[Corporal#United States Marine Corps|corporal]] or [[Sergeant#Marine Corps|sergeant]]; the Army term "noncom" is no longer appropriate. * '''NCOIC''' – Non-Commissioned Officer In Charge, an NCO responsible for a group of Marines, but without the authority of a [[Officer (armed forces)|commissioned officer]]; somes also the senior enlisted Marine acting with the officer in charge. See also [[#O|OIC]] & [[#S|SNCOIC]]. * '''NJP''' or '''[[Ninja in popular culture|Ninja Punch]]''' – [[Non-judicial punishment|Non-Judicial Punishment]], a legal proceeding much like a [[court-martial#Courts-martial in the United States|court-martial]] of much smaller scope. A commanding officer is authorized to issue summary punishments at [[#O|office hours]] (called [[#C|Captain's Mast]] afloat) under Article 15, [[Uniform Code of Military Justice|UCMJ]], to punish offenses too serious to be dealt with by a mere rebuke, but not serious enough to warrant court-martial. * '''NMCI''' – [[Navy/Marine Corps Intranet]], the program that outsources garrison [[information technology]] services for the [[United States Department of the Navy|Department of the Navy]], sometimes jokingly referred to as "Non-[[availability|Mission-Capable]] Internet".<ref>[http://abumuqawama.blogspot.com/2008/12/non-mission-capable-internet.html Non Mission Capable Internet] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081212084847/http://abumuqawama.blogspot.com/2008/12/non-mission-capable-internet.html |date=December 12, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Boghie |url=http://boghieonyoursix.blogspot.com/2006/03/nmci-non-mission-capable-internet.html |title=Non Mission Capable Internet |publisher=Boghieonyoursix.blogspot.com |date=2006-03-21 |accessdate=2012-03-07}}</ref> * '''Non-rate''' – Junior to the NCO ranks: a [[Private (rank)#United States Marine Corps|Private]], [[Private first class#United States Marine Corps|Private First Class]], or [[Lance corporal#Marine Corps|Lance Corporal]]; borrowed from naval use, where personnel below the [[petty officer]] ranks had no [[Naval rating|rating]], thus "non-rated men." * '''No impact, no idea''' – Expression denoting a miss on a [[shooting range|weapons range]] (the scorer cannot find an impact on target); also used as an "I don't know" response. * '''North Carolina Lawn Dart''' – Expression denoting the AV-8 and the many mishaps that took place during the aircraft's development and testing. * '''NROTC''' – [[Naval Reserve Officer Training Corps]], a [[college]]-based recruiting program for officers for the Navy and Marine Corps.
==O== [[File:USMC OCS logo.png|thumb|right|150px|[[Officer Candidates School (U.S. Marine Corps)|OCS]] logo]]
* '''OCONUS''' – Outside [[Continental United States|CONtinental United States]], as opposed to [[#C|CONUS]]. * '''O-Course''' – [[Obstacle course]]. * '''OCS''' – [[Officer Candidates School (U.S. Marine Corps)|Officer Candidate School]], recruit training for officers. * '''O-dark thirty''' – Very early hours before [[dawn]]. See also [[#M|military time]], [[#Z|Zero-dark thirty]]. The custom of saying "oh" instead of zero has diminished, but remains in this expression. * '''Office Hours''' – Administrative ceremony where legal, disciplinary, and other matters (such as praise, special requests, etc.) are attended, designed to dramatize praise and admonition, in a dignified, disciplined manner, out of the ordinary routine. Known as [[#C|Captain's Mast]] afloat. An award given during a positive office hours or Mast is known as a Meritorious Mast, a negative office hours with punishment awarded is an example of non-judicial punishment. * '''Officers' Country''' – Living spaces for officers aboard ship, or portion of post or station allocated for the exclusive use of officers. * '''Oki''' – [[Okinawa Prefecture|Okinawa]]. * '''Old Asia Hand''' – Person with more than one tour in Asia. * '''Old Man''' – Very informal nickname for the commanding officer, considered an inappropriate [[term of endearment]] for use by a junior, thus used in reference but never in address. * '''OMPF''' – Official Military Personnel File, a record of all awards, punishments, training, and other records compiled by [[Headquarters Marine Corps]]. * '''[[Oorah (Marines)|Oorah]]''' – Spirited cry used since the mid-20th century, comparable to [[Hooah]] used in the Army or [[Hooyah]] by [[United States Navy SEALs|Navy SEAL]]s; most commonly used to respond to a verbal greeting or as an expression of enthusiasm. The origin is often disputed. <!-- if you want to add more to this, please edit the [[oorah|oorah (Marines)]] article instead/first. --> * '''OP''' – [[Observation post|Observation Post]], a position used for [[reconnaissance]]; also, the post newspaper of [[Marine Corps Air Ground Combat Center Twentynine Palms]]. * '''OQR''' – [[Officer Qualification Record (OQR)|Officer Qualification Record]], a service record for officers, much like an enlisted Marine's [[#S|SRB]]. * '''OOB''' – Out Of Bounds, or straying into an area restricted from use by normal traffic, prohibited to Marines, or too far from base for a given [[#L|liberty]] period. * '''OOD''' – Officer Of the Deck, or the senior Marine responsible for the patrol and security of a unit's garrison working spaces and sleeping quarters after working hours, usually responsible for subordinate sentries and acts as a guard commander. See also [[#D|duty]] & [[#F|firewatch]] * '''Oscar Mike''' – On the Move, the names of the two NATO phonetic alphabet letters O and M, which stand for the phrase. Used on the radio and in shorthand to each other. See also [[ICAO spelling alphabet|NATO phonetic alphabet]]
<!-- OTV image above --> * '''OTV''' – [[Interceptor body armor|Outer Tactical Vest]], militarized version of Interceptor body armor, a common type of [[ballistic vest]]; being replaced by the [[Modular Tactical Vest|MTV]]. * '''Outside''' – Civilian life after discharge. See also [[#R|real world]]. * '''Overhead''' – [[Ceiling]]. * '''Over the Hill''' – Excessively old, or a Marine so long in the service they have become institutionalized.
==P==
[[File:Military chaplain2.jpg|thumb|150px|right|''[[Military chaplain|padre]]'' conducting mass]] * '''''[[Military Chaplain|padre]]''''' – [[Military chaplain|chaplain]], usually [[Catholic]], from the [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Italian language|Italian]] terms for "father". * '''PALS''' – [[Pouch Attachment Ladder System]], a webbing system used to attach combat accessories to [[MOLLE (military)|MOLLE]] and [[Improved Load Bearing Equipment|ILBE]] equipment. *'''Page 11''' – NAVMC 118(11), a page of a Marine's [[#S|Service Record Book]] or [[Officer Qualification Record (OQR)|Officer Qualification Record]] where administrative remarks are made concerning a Marine's performance and conduct, and which may contain negative recommendations regarding promotion or re-enlistment; while not a punishment itself or inherently negative, it is part of a Marine's permanent service record and used as a basis for administrative decisions regarding a Marine's career; the term commonly refers to an entry itself made in this section. * '''Parade Deck''' – Area set aside for the conduct of parades, drill, and ceremonies, often paved or well-maintained lawn. See also [[#G|grinder]]. * '''Paradise Island''' – Nickname for [[Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island]]. * '''Passageway''' – Corridor or hallway. * '''Passed over''' – Having failed selection for the next higher rank (for [[#S|SNCO]]s and officers). * '''[[Pay Grade]]''' – [[United States Department of Defense|DOD]] system of designating a U.S. serviceperson's pay (E-1 through E-9, W-1 through W-5, and O-1 through O-10), not to be confused with [[United States Marine Corps rank insignia|rank]] (though the two usually correspond) or [[billet]]. * '''PCP''' – Physical Conditioning Program, exercise regimen for Marines failing to meet the minimum physical requirements; also Physical Conditioning Platoon, for the unit where a physically unfit recruit is sent prior to [[recruit training]], nicknamed '''Pork Chop Platoon'''. * '''PCS''' – Permanent Change of Station, transfer to another [[List of United States Marine Corps installations|post, station, base, or installation]]. * '''PFC''' – [[Private first class#United States Marine Corps|Private First Class]]. * '''PFT''' – [[United States Marine Corps Physical Fitness Test|Physical Fitness Test]], a semiannual test measuring strength, agility, and endurance by scoring performance in [[chin-up|pull-up]]s (flexed-arm hang for females), abdominal [[crunch (exercise)|crunches]], and a 3-mile run. * PRT – Physical Readiness Test, an annual test conducted in utilities, with rifle and web gear. consisted of a rope climb, step-ups, fireman's carry, fire & maneuver course and a 3-mile run. * '''Phrog''' – Nickname for [[Boeing Vertol CH-46 Sea Knight|CH-46 Sea Knight]]. * '''Phone Watch''' – Duty where a Marine is responsible for answering phones when others are busy or unavailable (such as lunch hours); also the person filling the duty. * '''PI''' – [[Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island]]; formerly also [[Philippine Islands]], a frequent port of call for Pacific Marines until 1992 * '''Pickle Suit''' – [[Uniforms of the United States Marine Corps|Service "A" uniform]], from its all over green appearance.
[[File:Fourragère CG.png|thumb|150px|right|[[Fourragère#France|pogey rope]]]]
* '''Pinning''' or '''Pinning On''' – Promotion by pinning the new rank insignia onto the [[Marine Corps Combat Utility Uniform|MCCUU]] collar; also a form of [[hazing]] by [[Blood wings|striking the pins]] into the wearer's chest. * '''Pisscutter''' – Nickname for soft green [[garrison cap]] worn with the [[Uniforms of the United States Marine Corps#Service uniform|service uniform]].<ref>{{cite web |title = Marine Corps Uniforms |publisher = Marine For Life |url = http://www.hqmc.net/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=47&Itemid=29 |accessdate = 2008-07-17 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090823055211/http://www.hqmc.net/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=47&Itemid=29 |archivedate = 2009-08-23 |df = }}</ref> See also [[#F|fore-and-aft cap]].
* '''(The) Pits''' – Depressed area on a [[shooting range]] where the targets are located, shooters staff it by marking, raising, and lowering targets from behind a [[berm]].<ref>[http://www.lejeune.usmc.mil/wtbn/WTBN%20S3/Red%20Blanket.doc BLANKET SAFETY PROCEDURES FOR RANGES] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926232504/http://www.lejeune.usmc.mil/wtbn/WTBN%20S3/Red%20Blanket.doc |date=2011-09-26 }} by [[Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune|Camp Lejeune Weapons and Training Battalion]]</ref> See also [[#B|butts]] and pulling butts / pits. * '''Pitting''' – Incentive training for a large group of recruits, so named for the sandy pits set aside for such events.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} See also [[#Q|quarterdecking]]. * '''Pizza Box''' – The Marksman [[Weapons Qualification Badge]], so named for its square shape. * '''Pizza Stain''' – A nickname used by some Marines during recruit training to refer to the [[National Defense Service Medal]], so named for the red and yellow appearance, like the cheese and sauce of a pizza. * '''Platoon Sergeant''' – [[#S|SNCO]] executive to the platoon commander, usually the senior enlisted man. * '''PMCM''' – Equipment such as aircraft that are partially mission capable due to maintenance that needs to be performed. Parts are available but not manpower. * '''PMCS''' – [[Preventive Maintenance Checks and Services]], regularly performed maintenance on equipment, as opposed to corrective maintenance. Also, partial mission capability of equipment such as aircraft due to parts shortage in the supply chain. * '''PMO''' – [[Provost Marshal]]'s Office, the [[military police]] force of a Marine installation. * '''P.O.A.''' – [[Position Of Attention]] [http://www.drillpad.net/DPattention(M).htm]. * '''[[Pogue]]''' – Marine not of the combat arms ([[infantry]]), [[etymology]] is disputed: possibly "pogue" derived from the [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] word meaning "prostitute" or the [[Irish language|Erse Gaelic]] word meaning "to kiss [my ass]", while "POG" could be from the acronym Persons Other than [[#G|Grunt]], but could be a [[backronym]]. * '''Poguey''' or '''Pogey Bait''' – Candy or sweets. See also [[#G|geedunk]].
<!-- poguey rope image above --> * '''Poguey''' or '''Pogey Rope''' – The French [[Fourragère]] authorized for wear by members of the [[5th Marine Regiment (United States)|5th]] and [[6th Marine Regiment (United States)|6th Marine Regiments]]. * '''Police''' – To pick up items (such as litter or expended ammunition casings), to return an area to a natural state, or to correct another Marine. * '''Poncho Liner''' – Insulating [[blanket]] used to warm the individual wearing a rain poncho, often used as a stand-alone blanket.
<!-- * '''poolee''' – TBD --> * '''Pop Smoke''' – To leave quickly or hastily; from the method of throwing a [[smoke grenade]] to mark a [[Landing Zone|landing zone]] or conceal a [[Withdrawal (military)|retreat]]. * '''[[Port (nautical)|Port]]''' – Naval term for "left side of ship" when on board a ship and facing forward, opposite of [[starboard]]. "Port" is the same with respect to a ship regardless of where a person is located or which way a person is facing, whereas "left" might be ambiguous. * '''[[Porthole]]s''' – [[GI glasses|military issue eyeglasses]], or the wearer of glasses. See also [[#B|BCGs]] & [[#R|RPGs]]. * '''Pot Shack''' – Place where cooking utensils are washed. * '''Possible''' – Slang term for the highest score possible in a marksmanship exercise as in "shooting a possible"; used on the rifle range during [[Recruit Training]] to denote the shooter possibly achieving a perfect score in a given round of firing. * '''Pos''' – Radio lingo for position. * '''PowerPoint Ranger''' – Pejorative for Marines (usually officers) who have spent too much time in an office. * '''Prick''' – Slang for any equipment bearing the "PRC" [[Joint Electronics Type Designation System|JETDS]] designator, usually man-portable radios. * '''Pro & Cons''' – Contraction of "Proficiency and Conduct marks", a numeric system for evaluating enlisted Marines. Usually written or spoken consecutively, with the first being Proficiency and the second being Conduct, e.g. 4.5/4.8. Hypothetically, the scale is from 0.0 to 5.0, but a perfect 5.0 is so rare that a Marine who receives it is called a "water-walker" (in reference to Mark 6:48) and the worst marks awarded almost never fall below 2.0 . * '''Property Cage''' – Place where organizational property is stored, often a [[warehouse]]. * '''PT''' – [[Sports training|Physical Training]], [[physical exercise]] to build or maintain strength, agility, and flexibility. * '''Pucker Factor''' – High level of anxiety experienced by those in tight situations, usually aircrew. * '''Pull Butts''' – To mark and score targets on a [[shooting range]] from behind a [[berm]]. See also [[#B|butts]] & pits. * '''PX''' – [[Post eXchange]]; more properly the [[#M|Marine Corps Exchange]].
==Q==
* '''QRF''' – Quick Reaction Force, a highly mobile stand-by force designed to add firepower in precise places as the commander decides on a changing battlefield, often used for [[MEDEVAC]] purposes. * '''Quarter Deck''' – A location of prominence in a barracks or office; in [[recruit training]], this area by the drill instructor's office is usually off-limits to recruits except during ceremonial discipline; the term comes from the [[Lower deck|quarter deck of a ship]] defined as "the part of the upper deck [[abaft]] the [[Mast (sailing)|mainmast]], including the [[poop deck]] when there is one. Usually reserved for ship's officers, guests, and passengers."
* '''Quarterdecking''' – [[#I|Incentive training]] at [[recruit training]] by means of repetitive and constant physical exercises, so named because it is usually a recruit's only opportunity to visit the quarter deck. See also [[#P|pitting]]. * '''Quarters''' – Housing, whether bachelor (barracks) or family (government-leased apartments or houses); or periodic, muster of a ship's company. * '''[[Quatrefoil#In military|Quatrefoil]]''' – Four-pointed embroidered pattern stitched on to the top of a Marine officer's barracks cover, from the tradition of wearing it to be identified as friendly to Marine sharpshooters during boarding actions in the era of wooden sailing ships.
==R==
